I was at the gardens at the Red Cow, at Dalston—I saw my brother and Sumner there about eight o'clock, to the best of my recollection—I believe Sumner was rather partial to me—I cannot say how long they remained there, I should say a quarter of an hour, or twenty minutes—I cannot say what time I went to the gardens.

COURT. Q. What time did you get there? A. It was past seven o'clock—I went from my mother's house—I left there about half-past six o'clock-my cousin, Alfred Wright, was there, and the family—I drank tea with them, and they saw me go out—I did not tell them where I was going; I told my mother—I went out before my mother—I left her there at half-past six.

WILLIAM HACKETT . I live at 191, High-street, Hoxton—I know Sumner and Flaxton, and Flax ton's father—he is a watchman—my shop is a stationer's; it is opened on Sundays—Flaxton and Sumner frequently come to my house on Sunday nights to put up the shutters—they have done so frequently for these two years past—my shop is about 100 yards from the mother's—in coming from Dalston to my house persons would have to go along Kingsland-road—they have borne a good character as far as I know—the father was paid for putting the shutters up, and when he did not come, they were paid—my shutters are put up from nine o'clock to half-past nine—we sell newspapers and stationery—the prisoner carried out newspapers for me, nothing else.
JOHN WILSON —(the Prisoner, sworn), These two prisoners were not with me on the night of Sunday, 25th February—they are not acquaintances of mine—I never saw them before.

COURT. Q. Who were the persons that were with you that got awiy? A. I do not wish to answer—there were two men: I do not know them—I had not known them above a week—I do not know their names—one was called Bill and the other Tom. Sumner received a good character.)

FLAXTON and SUMNER—
NOT GUILTY .

987.
EMMA FORD and
JANE HOWDEN
, robbery on
Andrew Henry Moody, and stealing from his person 1 half-crown, 6 shillings, and 4 sixpences, his moneys. MR. EWART conducted the Prosecution,

p.hi: Andrew Henry Moody did not appear.

div1.p: CHALKS HATTON (policeman, G 203). I was on duty in Field-lane on the night of 13th March—I was attracted by some cries from No. 1, West-street—I listened and heard some one cry, "Let me go; let me get up"—I pushed the door open, and saw the prisoners on Moody, striking him—when they saw me, they both sprang off him—he came to me and said he had been robbed of a half-crown and ten shillings—he said they had bitten his hand; there were the marks on it—he said his name was Andrew Henry Moody—he was intoxicated, but was capable of knowing what he was doing—the prisoners said they had not robbed him, and they called him a thief—it is a brothel—nothing was found on the prisoners—their violence was excessive—the man was quite exhausted.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Were there two other women in the
Room? A. Yes; but only the prisoners were beating him—they said the; knew nothing of what had happened.
FORD. Aged. 26
HOWDEN. Aged. 21.

GUILTY of an Assault. —
Confined One Year

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE; Mr. Ald. SALOMONS; Mr. Ald. CARDEN; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq., and the Fistt Jury.

div1.p:
988.
JOHN MCCARTHY
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of a man unknown, from his person; having been before convicted.

ROBERT RANDALL . I live in Goodman's-fields. On 20th March, about ten minutes past three o'clock, I was on Tower-hill, looking at the soldiers, and saw the prisoner take a handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, and put it into his trowsers pocket—the gentleman walked away—I gave the prisoner in charge.

WILLIAM COOPER (policeman, H 198). Randall pointed out the prisoner to me—he ran away, a man stopped him—I took him, and felt his pockets, bat could find no handkerchief—he said he had not taken no handkerchief—we had not walked many yards before it came out at the bottom of his trowsers—he said at the station a man gave it him.
DANIEL LYONS (policeman). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction—(read—Convicted Aug., 1847—having been before convicted—confined twelve months)—I was present—he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

989.
CHARLES GARRETT
, stealing 1 waistcoat, value 1s. the goods of
James Hampton; having been before convicted.

JAMES HAMPTON, I live at Granville-place, Clerkenwell—the prisoner lodged with me about five weeks, and left on 5th March, and in three or four days I missed a waistcoat, which I had seen safe about a week before he left—this is it (produced)—I met him with it on, and gave him in custody on another charge.
Prisoner. You sold it to me. Witness. No; I did not.
SAMUEL MARKS (policeman). I took the prisoner.

WILLIAM DAWSON . I produce a certificate—(read—Charles Garrett convicted Feb., 1848—confined six months)—I was present—he is the man.
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined TWELVE Months.

990.
HENRY GILLINGHAM
, stealing 1 cistern, value 10s.; the goods of
Elisha Underwood, his master.

GEORGE RODWELL (policeman, B 205). On 22d March I went to a marine store-dealer's shop in Tothill-street, and saw the prisoner with a leaden cistern in the scale; I asked him how he came by it, he said he had it from 47, Regent-street, where he had been cleaning a house for Mr. Underwood, who gave it him.

ELISHA UNDERWOOD . 1 sell beer—the prisoner was in my service about six months—this cistern is mine—I do not know when it was taken, as it was fixed in a wooden case—I did not give it to the prisoner to sell.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

991.
JOHN KING
, stealing 1 chest, 20lbs. of coffee, and 2 tablets, value 21.5s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert Snowden; having been before convicted.

WILLIAM WAKEFIELD . I assist Robert Snowden, my brother-in-law. On 12th March, about a quarter-past five o'clock, I saw this chest in the street, with some coffee and two show-tablets in it, ready for Pickford's to take away, with other cases—somebody told me something, I opened the door and a boy pointed out the prisoner; I followed him, he ran, was stopped, and I took him—I passed the chest as I ran—it is worth 2l. 5s., and is Robert Snowden's property.

WILLIAM WRIGHT . I am errand-boy to Mr. Robert Snowden. About a quarter-past four, on 12th March, I was up-stairs, cleaning windows—I heard my mistress holloa; went down, and saw the prisoner drop the chest of coffee about twelve yards from the house—I called Stop thief!" and pointed him out to Mr. Wakefield; a cabman stopped him—I ran too, and did not lose sight of him—I am sure he is the man.
THOMAS EVANS (policeman, G 145). The prisoner was brought to the station—I told him the charge; he said he knew nothing about it, he was merely passing along—he was very much out of breath.

EDWARD RICH ('policeman, G 122). On the afternoon of 12th Feb. I was at home, and saw the prisoner and two others loitering about—the prisoner took this chest—I was lame but I opened the window and sprung my rattle, and called "Stop thief!"—he dropped it and ran away.
JAMES BRANNAN (police-inspector). I produce a certificate (read—Joseph Holland, convicted Dec, 1847; confined one month)—I was present—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY .** Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years.

992.
WILLIAM PORTER
, stealing 2s. 6d.; the moneys of
William Catley, his master.

SARAH CATLEY . Jam wife of William Catley, of 35, Little Church-street—the prisoner was in his employ—on 9th April I gave him half-a-crown to get changed—he never came back to breakfast—the policeman brought him about half-past twelve o'clock.

WILLIAM CLEMENTS . I work for Mr. Catley—I went after the prisoner and found him at Chalk-farm fair—I said I had come for the half-crown, and asked him to come back—he said he should come back when he liked; he bad lost it—I gave him in charge.
ROBERT GODFREY (policeman). I took the prisoner—he said he had lost the money—I found 1s. 5d. on him.
Prisoner I am sorry I did it—I was going to buy a new shirt with it.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—Strongly recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month ,

993.
MARY KINSDALE and
ALBERT PRIOR
, stealing 1 watch and 2 seals, value 61. 10.?.; the goods of
Robert Harvey, from his person.

ROBERT HARVEY (policeman D 48). On 29th March, at night, I was in Birdcage-walk, in plain clothes, going home, and saw and passed Prior and another man—I went on a short distance, and met Hicks, the policeman, on the beat—I spoke to him and looked at my watch; it was seven minutes past eleven o'clock—I put it in my waistcoat-pocket—my coat was buttoned one button at the top, it was single-breasted—the watch was attached to a silk guard round my neck—I then passed Kinsdale—she was about twenty yards from Prior—I walked past her about twelve yards—Hicks said something and I went back and looked at her—she said something I did not understand,

threw one arm round me and said, "Come along with me, my dear"—the kept running against me till I went against the iron railings, and then heard the click of scissors—I collared her, and said, "You have got my watch"—she coughed—Prior and another man came up and said, "Do not hurt the poor woman"—she had the watch in her hand, and offered it to Prior, who put out his hand to take it—I struck her on the face and knocked her down, as she fell she threw the watch out of her hand—I sprang at Prior and said, "I will have you too," but he pulled himself away and ran—I picked the watch up three or four yards off—a gentleman came up, picked up the seals, and gave them to me—these are them; they are mine, and the watch—I found part of the guard round my neck and the other part on the watch—Prior and his com
panion joined two females, and went on as if nothing had happened—I pointed him out to Hicks—Prior said I was mistaken, he was a gentleman, and if he was locked up it should cost me some money.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Did you turn round and look at Kinsdale? A. After I had passed her twelve yards—there was no conversation between us—Hicks did not go back with me; he went slowly on—I went back in consequence of what he told me, to see if I knew Kinsdale—I did know her—she gave me no trouble to take her—she called "Police!" and "Murder!" as she fell—Prior had come up before that; he was there when I knocked her down—I should not have done so if she had been by herself—I did not stand over her—I will not swear I saw the watch in her hand, but I saw something shining—I told the Magistrate so.

THOMAS HICKS (policeman, A 57). On the evening of 29th March I was in Birdcage-walk, and saw Kinsdale and a young man who told me something, and I watched her—Prior and another man walked on behind, twenty yards off, or little more—Harvey overtook me, and we walked together past Kinsdale—when about eight or ten yards from her, Harvey turned back, and I looked round—I was then about twenty yards from them, and saw Kinsdale catch hold of Harvey round the middle—in about two minutes she screamed "Police! Murder!"—I ran up and said, "What is the matter?" he said, "I have been robbed; go and take that man," pointing to one—I went after him; another man who was with him ran away—I caught Prior—he did not run—he said, "What is the matter?"—I took him back and took Kinsdale.

Cross-examined. Q. Why did you turn round? A. Because I did not like the looks of the woman—three or four persons ran at the cry of "Police," Kinsdale was then on the ground, and Prior was walking across the road, about thirty yards off.

JAMBS MARTIN (policeman, A 124). I was on duty at the station when the prisoners were brought—they were placed in cells next to each other—in consequence of directions I placed myself in an adjoining cell and heard their conversation—I made this memorandum afterwards, as they were all crack words, but I recollect it without that—Prior said, "I ought not to have said I came from the other side of the lombard"—Kinsdale said, "You have done it, and there is ten stretch hanging to your house" (meaning ten years)—Kinsdale said something I could not hear, the last words were,"don't you tumble"—he said "earwig, earwig," (meaning somebody listening)—they were then silent—she then said, "We can make up our minds for ten stretch each;" he said, ""No"—she said, "It is all your fault;" he said,"You ought to have walked"—she said, "How could I? when I was knocked down; I ought to have cracked the head, ought not I?" he said, "Never mind, it is no consequence now."
Cross-examined. Q. Who told you to watch? A. I was placed there by

Inspector Land, to see that there was no strangulation; he told me to place, myself so that I could hear and see what passed—I had never done so before—I was there about an hour—I wrote it down afterwards in the station—the serjeant and a constable were there—I did not tell them what I was writing; I told them afterwards.

WILLIAM MUNN . I was in Birdcage-walk about ten minutes past eleven o'clock, taking two females home, and saw Harvey with Kinsdale in his arms—Prior and another man were there, and said, "Don't hurt the woman,"—Harvey knocked her down—Prior said, "The d----d fool is mad; the man is mad"—they then went, at a gentle pace, along the road—I kept my eye on them—Hicks came up and ran after them—he dodged the other man round the path, and fell on the pavement—I kept my eye on Prior and gave him in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. How far did Hicks run after the other man? A. Twenty yards; we were about sixty yards from where Kinsdale lay.
HENRY HUNT (policeman, M 82). I produce a certificate—(read—Albert Grainger, convicted Dec. 1845, of stealing a watch from the person, cmfined six months)—I was present—Prior is the man.

KINSDALE—
GUILTY .—

Aged 28—
Confined Twelve Months.

PRIOR—
GUILTY .* Aged 28.—
Transported for Ten Years.

994.
CHARLES WELLS was indicted
for bigamy.
ROBERT JOHN LETTICE . I am acting parish-clerk of St. Pancras; I produce the registry. On 2d Feb., 1838, I find the marriage of Charles Wells and Halley Burke by banns.
JOHN YATES . In Feb., 1838, I was beadle of St. Pancras—I find my name here as a witness to this marriage—I can swear to the woman, and believe the prisoner to be the man.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How many hundred couples have you seen married since. A. It it impossible for me to say.

JOHN POOLEY (policeman). On 6th March, Halley Wells came to the station and told me something, in consequence of which I took the prisoner; he said he was very glad she gave him in charge, for he wished to have it settled one way or the other.
NOT GUILTY .

995.
HENRY HAYMAN and
LANCELOT WILSON
, feloniously cutting and wounding
John Hughes on the thigh, on the High seas, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

p.rs: (Mr. Ross, surgeon, stating that John Hughes was too ill to be examined, the COURT discharged the Jury from giving any verdict,)

div1.p:
996.
WILLIAM WILLIS
, stealing two table-cloths and five napkins, value 11.; the goods of
John Walton; 3d and 4th COUNTS, of Edward Ellice and othe rs.

THOMAS BALCHIN (City-policeman 618). About six o'clock on the evening of 4th April, I saw the prisoner in Petticoat-lane, with this bundle, and watched him into the Clothes' Exchange, and from thence to Carter-street—I asked him what he had got; he said some clothes—I examined the bundle and found these five dinner napkins and two table-cloths (produced).

DAWSON POULTER . I am clerk to the Reform Club—one of these napkins is the property of the Right Hon. Edward Ellice and others, the trustees of the Club—Walton is the husband of the laundress, who washes for the club—the whole of the napkins and table-cloths have the Reform Club mark on them, but I can only swear to this one as I marked it myself—they are made
expressly for the club, but the manufacturer may have sold others like them.

DENNIS CALLAGHAN . I am a carrier—at four o'clock on 24th March, I put two baskets of linen, from the Reform Club, into my cart, to take to my mistress, who is the wife of John Walton—I went into the Junior Club with another basket of linen, and, while there, somebody took away cart, horse and all—that was at a quarter-past four o'clock.
MARY FRENCH . I am housekeeper to the Reform Club—these articles are their property—I counted the articles myself, and put them into the basket—I saw Callaghan take them away.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw them publicly exposed in Petticoat-lane, and bought them to turn a penny.
NOT GUILTY .

997.
EDWARD MOORE and
CAROLINE BICKERS
, stealing 2 capes, 1 shawl, and 1 victorine, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Helen Mary Stocker: 1 shirt, 1 waistcoat, and other articles, value 16s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Bliss Stocker : to which BICKERSpleaded
GUILTY .

Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

THOMAS BLISS STOCKER . I live at Kentish-town; Bickers was my ap
prentice. On 24th Jan. I went to Church, leaving her at home—I came back about eight o'clock in the evening, and she was not there—I missed the articles stated—I had had the scarf safe within a week, and had spoken to Bickers about it—I said, "How is it that there is no one but you in the house, and this is the second scarf that is missing"—she said she knew nothing about it, where could she take it to—on 29th March I went with a policeman to 9, Tottenham-place, and found her lodging—there; and in a box, which I knew to be hers, I found these things (produced)—she acknowledged it—Moore was not there.

HELEN MARY STOCKER . I am the daughter of the last witness—this dress is my mother's, this cardinal and victorine are mine, and this shirt my father's—these blinds were safe in a drawer in my bed-room a day or two before Bickers left—the dress she has on is stolen.

WILLIAM RANSLEY (policeman, S 61). I went with Mr. Stocker to 9, Tottenham-place, and saw Bickers—I found these things, some in her boxes, and some in Moore's—I went again about a quarter-past four o'clock, and found Moore in the back kitchen—he said, "I suppose you are the man who has taken my wife away"—I said I had taken a female away, and must trouble him to go with me to the station—he said, "I will go; did you take anything out of that box?"—I said, "No"—he said, "Did you take anything out of that one?"—I said, "Yes"—he said, "That is my box"—going to the station I said I thought it was very foolish for him to have a young girl like her there—he said she was his wife, and then that she was not—he said he assisted in bringing the boxes away, but he did not know that any of the contents were stolen.

Moore's Defence. I am a widower; I fell into company with Bickers, and she said she had got a bad master and mistress, and no father or mother; and if I were willing she would come and live with me as my wife, and act as a mother to my child, to which I agreed; two or three weeks afterwards she asked me if I was in the same mind; I said, "Yes;" she said she would tell me when her month, or quarter, would be up, and if I would come at seven o'clock in the evening and fetch her things, she would go home with me; I brought her home on 24th Feb., I gave every thing into her possession, and

she said she would put my things to rights, and I have never looked into my boxes since; she has put some of my clothes into her boxes, and some of hers into mine; she said her master gave her the cloak.

MOORE—
NOT GUILTY .

998.
JOHN STONE
, stealing 1 iron gate, value 10s., fixed in a place dedicated to public use.

SAMUEL WEBBER . I am park-keeper of Victoria Park. On 8th April, about half-past eight o'clock in the afternoon, I followed the prisoner in the park with an iron gate; he left the park and went into a field—I asked him where he got the gate; he said a man gave it him, he dropped it, and attempted to start—I took him to the station, and found that the gate oame from the centre of the park.
THOMAS HENDRICK (policem an). Webber called me, and I took the prisoner—he said he was employed by a man to carry the gate for 6d.

GUILTY .* Aged 35.—
Confined Six Months

999.
WILLIAM SMITH and
ELIZA BUSHNELL
, stealing 46 yards of silk, value 6l.; the goods of
Joseph Hardwick, in his dwelling-house.
MR. ROBINSON conducted the Prosecution,

WILLIAM WARMAN . I am assistant to Joseph Hardwick, of 107, New Bond-street, linendraper On Saturday, 10th March, about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, Bushnell came and inquired for some Jenny Lind caps—we did not keep them—she went out and said something to Smith, who was outside, they both entered, and Bushnell asked for some white cotton stockings—she selected a pair, and then bought a white cambric handkerchief—Smith asked to look at some silk handkerchiefs, and selected one—he paid 9s., which the things came to—I packed up the parcel, and they rose to go away, and then Smith requested to be shown some silk dresses; I showed them some—Smith wanted something of a chocolate-striped colour—I showed them about twenty dresses, and said we had none of that description—they requested me to cut patterns of some which I had shown them—I packed some patterns up, and they rose up, and went five or six yards down the shop, when Bushnell said she wanted three or four yards of the pink silk for a child's frock; they both returned, and I cut off three yards and a half—Smith said "We must have some lining for it"—I went about six yards off and got the lining, which, with the silk, came to 12s. 6d.—I packed them up, and Smith paid me—Bushnell then stooped down—I asked what she was looking for; she said, "For a sixpence"—I went round the counter, and saw the corner of a silk dress projecting from under her shawl—I took it from her, and called a servant to search her—Smith rushed towards the door and tried to escape, a young man caught him, he came back, fell on his knees, and implored me to overlook it, and offered to pay any amount of money—I said I could do nothing of the kind—Bushnell went to a part of the counter where there were no silks and appeared to lean on it; when she moved, these two silk dresses were there, folded up in a way in which we never keep them—they were some I had shown her—Smith asked her if she had paid for those silks—I said he knew very well she had not—she was given in charge—these silks are worth 6l.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Has Mr. Hardwick any partner. A. No—there are silks infinitely more expensive than these.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. The dresses were all in a heap on the I counter? A. No, there were not more than three or four on one another—they were not scattered about in three or four places—the two silks I found were
about a yard from the others, I am confident—I am not mistaken about them, because it was at the very place where I had packed up the parcel.
ALFRED WILLIAM EVANS (policeman, E 106). I took the prisoners, and produce the silks.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. The man was Tery much agitated? A. Yes, and the woman also.

SMITH—
GUILTY .** Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years

BUSHNELL—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Ald. GIBBS; MR. RECOEDBE; Mr. Ald. WILLIAM HUNTER; Mr. Ald. CHALLIS; Mr. Ald. SIDNEY; and Mr. Ald. CARDEN.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Third Jury.

div1.p:
1000.
ELIZA WAGHORN
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Charles Gibson on the throat, with intent to murder him.—2d COUNT, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm. MR. ROBINSON
conducted the Prosecution.

JEMIMA BROWN . I am single, and occupy the first-floor front room at 2, New-court, Nicol-street, Bethnal-green—the prisoner lived next door, on the ground-floor. On the morning of 27th Feb., between two and three o'clock, a man named Sadler was in my room—he left me, and went down stairs in his shirt—Mary Day threw his trowsers down after him—I went down to look for a constable, and saw Gibson fighting with Sadler—Sadler came up-stairs again, and Gibson too—he was drunk—he tried to get into my room, but did not succeed—he then went over to Morris's room—I went out, and went down stairs—the prisoner rushed up-stairs into Morris's room, and said, "Oh you b—black mare!"—she ran to the dresser and took up a knife—Morris ran down stairs, and the prisoner after her, and she caught sight of Gibson, who was standing in his shirt, between Nos. 1 and 2 in the court, looking up to the window, and she drew the knife across his throat-Morris was at the bottom of the court, looking for a constable—it appeared to me that in the dark the prisoner mistook Gibson for Morris—when she had done it she said, "Oh my God! I have cut Charley Gibson's throat"—she was drunk—neither Gibson or the other man were acquainted with her—they did not visit her—she wiped the knife with a piece of cloth; I think a piece of a child's frock, and flung it up into Sarah Morris's room—she then laid hold of Gibson's head and said, "Oh my good God! Charley, I shall never rest upon my bed again, for I have cut your throat"—Gibson had then gone into the prisoner's room—she took a washing-basin up full of water end flung it up to Morris's window, saying, "You b—black mare, I will give you this in your face,"—the basin fell down on Gibson and smashed to pieces—I do not know what quarrel they had had—Morris was in bed when the two men were fighting—she had no quarrel with the men—I am quite sure it was the prisoner who cut Gibson's throat—I saw the knife in her hand, but she endeavoured to make it appear that Morris had done it.

Prisoner. Q. Where did I wipe the knife? A. Between the door and the court—I was standing outside the door, and she was outside—(The wit
ness's deposition being read, stated she wiped the knife with a cloth in her own room)—it was in the court that she wiped it. (The COURT entertained some doubt whether the intent to injure Gibson

could be supported, it being evident that the prisoner's violence was directed to another party; for although had he died, the offence would have been murder, yet to support the particular form of charge here made, the intent and the assault must concur. From the nature of the case the COURT thought it best to confine the inquiry to the assault only).

CHARLES GIBSON. I am a sawyer, and live at 3, New-court. On 27th, Feb. I came home drunk—I saw the prisoner that evening—we Were very good friends together—when the fight was over I was coming in-doors again, and directly I got against my own door I found my throat was out, and I tumbled down—I cannot say whether it was the prisoner did it, but there was nobody in the court but her and me, and she was crying—I was taken to the prisoner's room and laid upon the bed—I heard her say, "I shall never rest upon my bed any more, for, poor fellow, look how he bleeds! look how he bleeds!"—she said, "Dark Sally has cut poor Charley's throat with I knife, and chucked it up-stairs again"—she afterwards said, "I have cut his throat with the washhand basin; I did not intend to do it"—I swear she mentioned the word "washhand basin"—she said, "I shall never forgive myself any more"—when the basin was thrown up it did strike me—the instant it Was thrown I found my throat was cut—I do not know what it was cut It—I Was very tipsy—I was in the hospital a month, and have pot been able to work since.

MARY DAY . I was in the yard with Gibson, and saw the prisoner draw the knife across his throat—he fell down—about two minutes afterwards the basin was thrown up to the window, and it came down on Gibson's head—it did not break before it hit his head—it was meant for Sarah Morris.

WILLIAM WATKINS EDWARDS . I am house-surgeon at the London Hos
pital. Gibson was brought there on the morning of 27th Feb.—he had an incised wound across his throat—I should say such a knife as this produced would cause such a wound—I should say it was impossible for it to have been done by a basin being thrown up and falling upon him as he lay upon the ground—the wound was about two inches long between the chin and apple of the throat, and about half an inch deep—it wounded one of the branches of the carotid artery—he had lost a good deal of blood when he was brought—he would be very likely to fall instantly—he was under my care for a month.

Prisoner. Gibson told me the doctor had taken several pieces of china out of the poultice applied to his throat, and he had several pieces remaining under his chin. Witness. I have not seen any—I never heard of it till this moment—no complaint was made of the man's head—I noticed no abrasion, of the skin.

WILLIAM BROWN (policeman, H 111). I went into Morris's room abort half-past five, and found this knife upon the floor, in the same state as it if now—I found a cloth in the prisoner's room with marks of blood upon it, such as the wiping of a knife would produce—I believe there was blood upon the prisoner's apron—it was taken from her when she was taken into custody.

ROBERT GIFFORD (policeman, H 89). I took the prisoner the same night, several hours after—she was in bed, and when she dressed herself I took this apron from her (produced)—it is stained with blood in two or three parts.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw Sarah Morris pass me as Gibson stood at my left; I turned round and said, "Oh my God! dark Sally has cut his throat, and I said no more till he was carried into my room and laid upon my bed.

GUILTY of a most aggravated Assault. Aged 25.—
Confined Two Years.

1001.
ELIZA MITCHELL
, feloniously killing and slaying her bastard child: to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Two Years.

1002.
PETER LEITH
, feloniously killing and slaying
Solomon Abrams on the High seas.

RICHARD WILLIAM HAINES . I have been for several years in New Zealand, and came home as a seaman on board the ship Indian, of which the prisoner was chief mate—I joined her at Auckland; we sailed from there on 15th Oct—there was a Jew lad named Solomon Abrams employed on board the vessel in feeding the stock, which consisted of sheep, cows, goats, turkeys, fowls, and pigs—he continued to perform his duty till about 24th Nov., when he was not capable of doing so by weakness and illness—the vessel was then to the west of Cape Horn—I saw Abrams flogged the first time about a fortnight after we left Auckland—it was by the prisoner's orders, because he was dirty in the coalhole—he was flogged on the bare breach with a cat-o'-nine tails made of nine pieces of marline—he was lashed by his hands to the windlass, and had a dozen lashes—the first flogging did lot fetch the blood—he was flogged again about two days afterwards by the prisoner's order—that flogging drew the blood—he was about fifteen years old—he was in very good health when we left Auckland—I knew him on shore—I believe he was flogged the second time for the same reason as at first—the prisoner always flogged him himself—he had a dozen lashes on the second occasion—I do not know how often he was flogged afterwards—it night have been nearly every morning while we were on deck—I was in the chief mate's watch—I never knew him get more than two dozen—that continued until he took to his bed, about eight days before he died—he had no bed except what he brought on board—he slept in the galley, where the live stock were—I should not think he could keep himself clean there—the live stock caused more dirt than he could attend to—in the whole he wat flogged from eighteen to twenty times—I think he died between 1st and 5th Dec.—I never saw any one flog him but the prisoner—I saw the second mate strike him once—I have seen the prisoner strike him with the rope's-end—sometimes he was flogged at the windlass, sometimes over a bundle of hay, sometimes over the spars or over the guns; any place that was handy—his trowsers were always off, and he was stripped to his bare body when he was flogged—his hair was cut, by the chief mate's orders, close to his head—they said he had vermin in his hair, but I did not see any—I should think the vermin of the stock would have crawled to him where he slept—I saw him placed in a tub of cold water—we were then about 55 south latitude, and the weather was very cold—I should think there was about two feet six inches or three feet of water in the tub—the prisoner ordered him into the tub—he did not like to get in at first, and then the prisoner gave him a shove, and he ultimately went in—he had nothing but his shirt on then—as far as I can judge he was in the tub about an hour and a half—he was placed there to wash himself—he was not to say very filthy—he was dirty by knocking about the stock without shoes or stockings on—there was the manure of the animals on him—the prisoner used to come forward while he was in the tub and see if he was washing—he was washing his clothes—he was in a very weak state of health at that time—I did not see that his skin was broken—there was a very heavy fall of snow in the night, and in some parts of the poop it might have been six inches deep, and in some four—the boy shi
vered all the time he was in the water—after he had been flogged several

times he got full of sores, the same as any person flogged would—the sores never got well before he was flogged again, and that drew his bottom into a scab—I have often seen the blood come—the last flogging I saw him have was about eight days before he died—he got quite thin and weak—I first ob
served that about a fortnight before he died—I saw him flogged about three times after that—he slept on one side of the galley, the turkeys were on the other, right opposite him, and the sheep were under him—he could not help being dirty—there were no pigs in the galley; some were in the long-boat and some in the sty, which was between the long-boat and the galley, about two yards from where he slept—he had to clean the galley out every now and then to get the dung out—he had to tread in it when he got out of bed—the cook's galley was on deck exposed to the weather; if a heavy sea came over it must come into the galley—I never did see the sea come over—he slept in a place with a wooden covering and a partition from where the turkeys were—he slept on two boards put on the side, till he got a piece of plank put to keep him from falling out of bed—it was hard weather and cold while he slept there—that in my judgment was not a fit place for him or anybody to sleep in; I should not like to have slept there myself—I remember seeing him taken out one night, four or five days before he died, and placed on the fore-hatch—he was all over sores then, and was not sensible—I did not see any flogging after that—I went to see him after he took to his bed; I was not able to make him understand me—he often complained to me of his treatment before he took to his bed—he complained that he did not get his rations—the pri
soner always behaved well to me—there was no surgeon or medical person on board—about three weeks before he died his bowels began to get loose, and they continued so till he died—he was often flogged for his bowels being loose—he slept in different places—he was a very good-looking, smart boy when he came on board; tall and thin for his age—after he was dead I observed a lump in his neck, about the size of an egg; I never saw it before—I never saw the captain present when he was flogged—there were about sixteen men on board the vessel.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you know where this boy came from? A. Auckland—I do not know that he had been up the country—I never heard so from him—he was not a seaman—he lived with a person named Keasey, a general store-keeper—I knew him there about eight months—he had three places during that time—there might have been an inspector come on board when our ship came into the river; I did not see him—I went to the police-office the day after I landed—the day after I was paid by the captain; I received 2l.6s.—I did not receive my full amount; I ought to hare had about 3l. more—the captain stopped 3l., I do not know what for—I never heard the mate complain of my being idle or neglecting my work—the captain never told me the mate had complained—he might have said that on account of my sight being bad I was not able to do my duty as an able seaman; he never told me so—I embarked as an able seaman—I had been a mate before I embarked in this ship—Patterson had a defect in his eye—as far as I can judge, he did his duty as an able seaman—I do not know whether he was paid his wages, or what he received—he and I went to the Thames police-court to summons the master for our wages—I heard Pattersons summons was dismissed—I did not appear myself, because I was ill—I can
not swear whether we two were the only two who did not receive our wages—I was mate of the Sir John Franklin, of New Zealand—I did not run away from her, I was paid off—I got all my wages there—I was not charged with breaking into sume of the cargo—I did not take away any of the cargo—there

was a passenger on board the Sir John Franklin named Beattie—I have been in the navy, and left thirteen or fourteen years ago, because I thought I could do better—I did not get into any scrape there—I was never flogged—I have never been tried for anything—the last flogging Abrams received was eight or ten days before he died, and between that and the first flogging he had been flogged eighteen or twenty times—that might have been during a period of five weeks—that was before we rounded the Cape—he did not die till after we had passed the Falkland Islands—I swear I never saw the captain present when he was flogged, or heard him give any order for him to be flogged—the captain was very seldom on deck so early as four or six o'clock in the morning—it was generally then that the boy was flogged—they used to say that the boy was dirty, but I never saw it—I never heard the crew complain of it—the crew did not go up to the captain in a body and complain of his dirt, or I should have heard of it—when I saw his body I saw a few sores on his feet—they were scrubbed with sand, at the chief mate's orders, by the boy Herbert Taylor, an apprentice on board—they were small dry sores, just by the ankle, as if the skin had been knocked off, and they were healing—there were four or five of them, and I believe they were on both legs—I did not bear that he had got the venereal disease in the country—I have heard it talked about since the trial came on—I never heard of it on board—he never said anything about it, or said he was ill—if he had had the disease I think he would have come to me, knowing I had been so long in the country, and could judge of it—he never did come to me—there is a disease of that kind out there—Herbert Taylor had to rub his feet with a piece of canvass and sand, because his feet looked rather dirty—the first flogging was about a fort
night after we left Auckland, the next might be two days afterwards, and after that there was a flogging pretty nearly every other day—it generally took place between four and six, which was the chief mate's watch.

MATTHEW CAREY . I reside at 2, Queen's-court, Albert-street, Deptford. I was a seaman on board the Indian, and recollect Abrams coming on board at Auckland to feed the stock; he was then in a good slate of health to all appearance—there was a seaman, named Williams, on board, he com
plained to the prisoner that Abrams had vermin about his neck, and the prisoner ordered his hair to be cut—he made a mess on a sail, and the pri
soner said he should not sleep in the lower forecastle any more, and he went down again and made a mess in the coalhole, and the prisoner flogged him for it; that was about three weeks after he came on board, and I believe it was the first time he was flogged—after that he was kept on the forecastle, and we were forbidden to go near him, because he had got vermin—his dress consisted of a cotton shirt and a pair of duck-trowsers—it was not very cold weather then, but we were getting into cold weather—he was kept there when his hair was cut, from about eleven o'clock in the morning till three or four in the afternoon—he was not subject to that treatment every day, only on that particular day—we went below about twelve the next morning and saw a mess on a sail, and he said he could not get the hatch off; the hatch was put over, but it was easy enough for any one to lift it off if he had placed his head against it; I have done it myself easily—he was in the habit of sleep
ing in the forecastle till the day his hair was cut; he was then put down in the lower forecastle—he used to sleep in the top-gallant forecastle; there were not enough berths for the hands on board; he never had a berth assigned him with the rest of the seamen—he used to sleep on the chest, and every time the door was opened, he was exposed to the wind and weather—we had some very severe weather when we got off Cape Horn, and it was very cold

there; we had very heavy seas—he then slept in the galley—the coppers had been taken out of the galley, and put-under the top-gallant forecastle—the galley was worse than the forecastle to sleep in; it was more exposed to the weather—he was placed there by the captain's orders—there was a top to it and sides; one door was nailed up, and the other left open—he could not get out away from the dirt—it was not nearly so comfortable as the fore
castle—he had no hammock; he had a bed place, and two or three blankets—I know he had blankets, because I threw them overboard after he died, with his clothes—the mate gave me orders to do so, as they were in such a dirty state—I was in the mate's watch between four and six o'clock in the morning, that was when I saw Abrams flogged—I cannot say how often he was flogged; it might be more than a dozen times, or it might be less—I should not like to say he had not been flogged twenty times—I recollect his first flogging, that was for making a mess in the coalhole, about three weeks after he came on board—I do not recollect how many lashes he got then—I cannot tell how many days after that it was that he was flogged again; I think it was the next day; sometimes he used to get flogged every morning regularly—I suppose he was flogged eight, nine, or twelve times—his trowsers were pulled down, and he was flogged on the bottom, with a marline similar to this (produced)—he was flogged for being dirty—it is my belief that he was frightened to come out on deck in the night-time—I never knew him dirty himself in the day-time; he said he could not help it—there was stock on board, which was placed where he slept—I remember his being told to go and scrub his clothes in a tub—I was not there at the time—I cannot say whether he was put into the tub or not—he came to me to lend him my brush; I lent it him, and he was left there to scrub his clothes—I saw him scrubbing his clothes, but I did not see him in the tub—he was all wet at the time; it was cold weather—after he died, I saw two large black or blue lumps on each side of his throat—I remember his being flogged for stealing two bullocks' or calves' tongues, from the galley—he had his rations served out like the rest of the crew, by Mr. Senior, the steward—he got them regularly if he was there; if not, people that were hungry eat them themselves—his share was always cut, and if he left it, anybody ate it who could get hold of it—the crew are not all on deck when the rations are served out; one man is generally sent aft to see them weighed.

Cross-examined. Q. Were they uncooked tongues? A. Dressedtongnes, hung in the galley for cooking—he ate them without being cooked—he stole them out of the galley, and so would I at that time if I could have got hold of them—we were short of provisions; we did not have near enough bread to eat with the meat, and we were frightened to eat meat, because we had not a full allowance of water—that began after we came round Cape Horn—I got my wages paid me—I stuck to my work; Patterson did too—I never knew him to lay up, except two days—the cook found out that Abrams was dirty; he first complained of it to the mate—after that the crew went and complained—they one and all said he should not sleep in the forecastle—I do not know that it was the crew that made him change, because if the captain ordered him to sleep in the forecastle we could not deny it—his place was changed by the captain's order, I cannot say that he was flogged by the captain's order—we did not complain to the captain that he was dirty, only to the pri
soner—he was a very dirty boy—he dirtied himself almost every night—I never knew him to dirty himself till he was flogged—he was never flogged until he had dirtied over the sail—there was no occasion whatever for him to have done that—he was too lazy to get up—he was beaten so as to leave the marks—I

was never flogged—there might hare been five or six pieces of marline to the thing he was flogged with, and he was struck ten or twelve times—I saw the blood come—I cannot say when that was, but it was after two or three times—the tub was what we called the wash-tub, we all washed our clothes in it, and our faces and hands when we got up—we did not all get into it.

MR. PAYNE. Q. When this dirt was made on the sail how was the hatch? A. It was on, but not fastened—Abrams was not a regular sailor—the place where he slept was completely dark, you could not see your hand before you—Abraras said he knocked once or twice, but could not get the hatch open—I think if anybody had been there they would have heard it.

FREDERICK SAVILLE . I was a seaman on board the Indian. I recollect Abrams coming on board—he seemed to be in pretty good health then—seven or eight days after he came on board I saw the prisoner cut him across the back with the rope's end; he then had his clothes on—the first time he was regularly flogged was about three weeks after he came; that was across a truss of hay—I believe his hands were held and his clothes were down—the prisoner flogged him on the backside with a cat—I do not know how many strokes he had; they bruised him—I cannot tell what he was flogged for—from that time he used generally to be flogged every day—after he had been flogged be dirtied the place where he slept—the prisoner generally flogged him, sometimes with a rope's end, and I have seen him get a crack with a broomstick, or with a cat—I noticed that it had an effect upon his health about a week before he died—he then looked very bad indeed—I did not tee him flogged the last week—I remember his being put into a tub of water, it was in very cold weather indeed—the prisoner made him go in to wash his body—I do not know whether he was dirty—after he came out he had to wash his clothes too—I did not hear that he objected to go in—I did not see anything when he went into the tub—at the latter part of the time they said he was flogged for his dirtiness—I never heard the prisoner say anything about it—Abrams did not get food enough—I never heard any cause stated for hit being flogged except his dirtiness—he slept in the lower forecastle when he dirtied the sail—the batch was covered over, which would make it dark below—it was not battened down; he could easily get out.

Cross-examined. Q. You were not examined before the Magistrate? A. No; we were all on short allowance—we were all served alike—we had not enough bread or crater—there was enough meat—I do not know whether the mate was put on short allowance—we did not all complain of Abrams being dirty; a good many of us did—after he was dead I saw sores all over hit body—I did not see any on his ancles; I did not observe his legs—I only looked into the galley-door and saw them—I did not examine them—I cannot say whether the captain ordered the boy to be flogged or not—it is the rule of the ship for the mate to receive his orders from the captain—he was gene rally flogged when the captain was not on deck—I cannot tell whether it wat ever done when the captain was on deck.

JAMES PATTERSON . I was a sailor on board the Indian—I recollect Abrams coming on board at Auckland—he appeared to be in very good health then—I recollect his being flogged while the ship was on her voyage—I only saw him flogged twice with the cat—I should think the first flogging was about three weeks after we left Auckland—he was flogged by the chief-mate with the cat, for going into the lower forecastle and doing his business there—I do not know how many lashes he had—he was flogged again the next morning, or the morning after that—that was for a similar thing in the galley—the prisoner flogged him then with the cat—he was put over the end of the windlass and flogged—his hands were held—I do not exactly know

how many lashes he had; the cat was made of marline—on the last of these two occasions the blood flowed—he was in a very bad state, and after he was flogged, he was put in cold sea water, in a tub—I cannot say how long he was left there—he was put there to wash himself—he had a great number of floggings during the voyage—he was in a horrible state before he died; his feet were sore from going barefooted—he said his feet pained him—his drew was a very thin cotton shirt, and a thin pair of trousers—he was very weak and tick, and quite deranged five days before he died—he was not capable of helping himself—there was no surgeon on board; the captain used to give us medi
cine when we required it—I saw the captain and one of the passengers give him some medicine once, about a week or ten days before he died—he was more given to dirtiness at the latter part than he was at the commencement of the voyage; as his health got worse that habit increased—his bowels appeared weak, he said he could not unhook the galley.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you did not get your wages? A. Not all—I summoned the master, and the summons was dismissed; the mate was there, but he was not sworn; a charge was made against the mate then—that was before my summons came on; Haines made the charge first—I cannot say when that was exactly—I had no quarrel with the mate—he had not, to my knowledge, been the means of preventing me from having my full wages—the captain found fault because I did not steer the ship well.

JOHN BLKNNERHASSETT GODFREY , M.D. I am a surgeon at 3, Mount-place, London Hospital—I was surgeon on board Her Majesty's ship Diligence—I have seen the effects of flogging on the human system; diarrhoea and looseness of the bowels is one of the symptoms following upon it; if flogging is repeated from day to day fever is produced, and delirium gene
rally attends fever—I have heard the evidence, and am of opinion that the treatment the boy was said to have received and the flogging were sufficient to undermine his health, and cause death—I see no other cause; the repetition of these floggings would weaken the stomach, and produce a shock to the system.
Cross-examined. Q. Your opinion is founded on the supposition that the boy was healthy when he went on board? A. Yes.

HERBERT TAYLOR . I was an apprentice on board the Indian—I remember Abrams coming on board at Auckland, and the first night when he came on board I noticed that he had sore ancles—he was turned out of the forecastle by the men because he was lousy, and he went to the cook's galley, where the carpenter put up a bunk for him; he only slept there one night. About ten days or a fortnight after he came on board, I noticed that he used to dirty himself—his clothes were dirty—he looked healthy when he came on board—I have seen him dirty many times, and Mr. Leith has ordered him to put clean clothes on; he would take them off again as soon as Mr. Leith was gone—I only saw him whipped once, that was about eight o'clock in the morning, with a piece of marline, across the bottom—if he had been whipped twenty times I should have seen it—I was in the mate's watch—I have been whipped with a rope's-end, but not in the same way—he was whipped with some marline—I was always in Mr. Leith's watch, but was not always on deck—I have heard the men say, when I have come on deck, "Abrams has been whipped again"—I heard of his being flogged three times—I saw him in the tub once, washing: Mr. Leith told him to get in, and he went in—that was when his hair was cut—his head was one mass of vermin, and Mr. Leith put some ointment to it—he was in the tub about a quarter of an hour, and then came out and washed his clothes—it was then comparatively

warm weather, and about three weeks after we left Auckland—I never saw all hands called up to see him whipped—I never sailed with Mr. Leith before—he behaved kindly to me, and I would sail with him again.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you going to sail with him again? A. I cannot say; the Indian has sailed—Abrams knew nothing about the duties of a ship—this Was my first voyage—I was whipped when I deserved it, with a rope's-end, but never with a marline—it blew very hard off the "Horn," and there was a little snow—it was not six inches deep on the poop, not more than an inch—I did not see the boy in the tub off the "Horn"—I never heard him scream out—I have heard him say he would not do it again, and that he could not help it—he used to wash in the same tab that the men did—he never used to wash himself at all without he was told to do so.

JOHN SHEDDON . I was carpenter on board the Indian—I remember Abra
hams coming on board at Auckland—I noticed that his habits were dirty about a fortnight or three weeks afterwards, and he was put out of the fore
castle on the complaint of the men—I made him a bunk in the top-gallant forecastle, it was protected from the weather—when he came on board he looked healthy and clean—after he was put into the galley I saw large black dry sores breaking out upon him—he was only in the galley two nights—he then went in among the stock for his own pleasure, no one forced him to go—he was a dirty, filthy boy—he then went into the lower forecastle, which was a comfortable plate to sleep in—there were sails there, and worn to hang up a hammock; I cannot say whether he had one—the burden of the vessel was 560 tons—half of the seamen had not beds, only bunks—the boy was better off in the lower forecastle than the men, and more clear of the weather—there was no hardship in placing him there—the first time I noticed these boils upon him was sixteen or seventeen days before his last illness—Mr. Leith paid every attention to him for eighteen or twenty days before he died—he was not whipped to my knowledge during that time—he would go to him, and order him clean things, he gave him two cotton shirts of his own—I never saw a cat-o'-ninetails on board—I saw the boy corrected three times for his filth and dirt, and that was all—I noticed a dry sore on the boy's finger on his left hand about three weeks before he died; the flesh was eaten right away—he has spoken to me about his habits at New Zealand, which might relate to that disease—the animals on board had no distase, nor any vermin that I know of—he slept on a rack that was made for the sheep, and was about four feet from the turkeys—he would never change his clothes except Mr. Leith would go and stand over him, and as soon as his back was turned he would take them off, and put on his dirty ones again—I have seen that more than once, twice, or thrice—his uncleanly habits lid not commence with his going to live with the stock—I should say, from the state of his head, he must have had lice months before he came on board—the skin was half off his head—he was turned out of the galley for being dirty in the saucepan in which the cook was cooking daily—his bowels were not loose at that time—I saw him in the tub for about five minutes, and every man was in it, more or less—I was in it—he did not stand in it for two hours, or an hour and a half, off the Horn—I never saw him in it but once, and that was for about five minutes—the weather was then quite mild.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. When was that? A. About three or four weeks before he died, six weeks before we got to Cape Horn—I think he died before we got there—we had snow and sleet off the Horn once—it was a month or five weeks before he died that Mr. Leith gave him the two

shirts—he looked a clean, healthy boy before he came aboard—he began to get dirty a fortnight or three weeks after—I only saw Mr. Leith correct him three times—I never saw a cat-o'-ninetails on board that or any ship I was ever in.
MR. PARRY. Q. Have you ever sailed with Mr. Leith before? A. No—he was a humane, well-conducted seaman, I only wish every one was like him—I am not going with him again; the Indian has sailed.

THOMAS BEATTIE . I was an able seaman on board the Indian, from Auck
land—I remember Abrams coming on board—about three weeks after we got to sea, I observed that his hands and feet were sore—he was labouring under a certain disease, known in New Zealand as the yhacyhac—I remember Mr. Leith ordering his hair to be cut, on account of the vermin—I have seen him whipped by Mr. Leith once or twice, and it was no more than he deserved—Mr. Leith's attention was called to his sores, and I never knew of his being whipped afterwards—he was very attentive to the boy—I have seen him order, and take him food and medicine, and give him clean linen, and stand by and see it changed—Robert Alexander called his attention to the boy's state four, five, or six weeks before his death—Mr. Leith was always liked by the crew—I had never sailed with him before.

COURT. Q. How did the boy seem for the first three weeks? A. He seemed healthy when he came on board, and did his work till we had some rough weather, ten or fifteen days after we sailed, and after that he was of no use

ROBERT ALEXANDER . I was an able seaman on board the Indian, from New Zealand—I remember Abrams being turned out of the forecastle on account of his dirtiness—I think that was better than three weeks after be came aboard—his hair was cut before that—I afterwards saw that he had on him a certain disease, which the natives of New Zealand call the yhacyhac—I saw boils on his hands and legs—I have seen the mate whip him, I cannot say how many times—the men were always growling about him to the mate he was very kind to the boy after I told him the state he was in.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How often used the boy to be whipped? A. I do not know: only when there was occasion for it—he was not flogged every time a complaint was made about his being dirty—as soon as the mate knew he was badly he knocked it off—I do not think he was flogged a dozen times altogether.

JOHN JOHNSON . I was a seaman on board the Indian—about three weeks after Abrahams had been on board, I saw he had some big dry sores on his hands and legs, and one on one finger—his feet swelled on account of his going without shoes—I have only sailed one voyage with Mr. Leith, be behaved kindly to me, and to the men generally.

COURT. Q. How often have you seen the boy flogged? A. Never—he looked clean and in good health when be came on board—he had a bed then—we turned him out of the forecastle because he was dirty—he never went aloft—he had been to sea before.

HENRY SENIOR . I was first steward on board the Indian, Abrams had not been on board above a week or ten days before he began to be lazy—I was present when his hair was cut on account of the vermin, his head was in a most filthy state, and also down his back and breast, he must have come on board in that state—he looked rather delicate when he came on board, but tidy and clean—about three weeks after he had been on board I noticed that he was full of sores about his legs and body, and one finger was completely

eaten to the bone—I never saw him whipped, and he was never out of my sight. THOMAS DOUGLAS. I was first steward on the homeward voyage. I remember Abrahams being turned out of the forecastle for being dirty—about three weeks after he had been on board I noticed that he had the disease upon him, it is there called the yhacyhac—I know what that is—I was in New Zealand four months. (WILLIAM SMITH and HENRY SAGE, surgeons, gave their opinion that, from the evidence in the case, the deceased had died from the effects of disease; but also stated that continued flogging might have accelerated his death: the details of their evidence were not of a nature fit for publication.)
GUILTY . Aged 21.—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Months.

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. COMMON SERJEANT; and Mr. Ald. CARDEN.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Sixth Jury.

div1.p:
1003.
GEORGE DAVIS,
MARGARET M'CARTHY , and
ANN WOOD
, for a robbery upon
John Byland, and stealing 1 watch, and other, articles, value 5l.; and 3 shillings; his property; and, before the said robbery, beating and striking him: Davis having been before convicted.

JOHN BYLAND . I am a journeyman dyer—I live in Long-alley, Shore
ditch. Between one and two o'clock on Saturday morning, 24th Feb., I was coming towards home—I had been drinking but very little; I knew what I was about—I met the two female prisoners in Whitechapel, went with them to a public-house, and had something there; and while we were there Davis and another man came in—they knew the females, and they had something to drink—I remained there two or three minutes, and then left with the females—Davis and his companion stopped a little while behind—they then followed us, I saw them walking behind us—when we came to George-street Davis gave me a blow on the right side of the head, which knocked me down—when I fell, the two girls held my hands, and Davis got on my chest with oil knees—I had a watch in a small watch-pocket in my waistcoat, a guard round my neck, and a small metal watch-key, which I used to carry in my pocket with my money—I had 4s. in money—while I was down, M'Carthy unbuttoned my waistcoat and coat, passed the watch-guard over my head, took my watch out of my pocket, and passed it to Wood—I called out, and struggled, and Davis said, "Let us murder the b—"—I got away, and met the policeman within two minutes—I told him What had happened, and returned with him to George-street—we saw M'Carthy against the door where it happened—I said, "That is one of the females"—we went up to her, and Davis was close by her—he said she was a respectable woman, and had been in his company all the evening—I told the policeman that I knew he was the man that knocked me down—I knew him by a scar on his cheek—he said he was not the man—I gave him in charge.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Were you perfectly sober? A. I was; I had had but two pints of ale the whole day—I had been to see a friend who was ill over at Lambeth—I staid there till past twelve o'clock—I came over London-bridge—I was not wandering about the streets—I was coming to Whitechapel—I have been married; I am not now—I had gone

with the two females to treat them, and then they happened to be walking my way down George-street, into Commercial-street—I walked outside them, not between them—McCarthy was standing at the door of a house when I returned, and I said she was one of the women, then Davis came up, and I said that was the man—I told the policeman I should know him from a thou
sand, by a scar on his right cheek—I gave him in charge, and then I saw the scar—I did not know either of the prisoners before, yet I positively swear to them—Davis first said he had been with M'Carthy all the evening, and she was respectable; and then he said he had been asleep in a coffee-house till a quarter past two, and that he had been to buy some tobacco—he said I must be mistaken, for she was in his company a few minutes before—there was nothing found on him—I am sure Wood had the watch.
McCarthy. Q. Had I a bonnet and shawl on when I was at the door? A. No, you had not—I do not know the sign of the public-house we went into in Whitechapel

Wood. You know there was no one but you and I that went into the public-house; we came out, and in Thrawl-street you stood talking with me; the policeman came, and said to you, "You don't know what you are doing," and you walked away towards Whitechapel; I left you in Brick-lane. Witness. I took you and M'Carthy into the public-house, and I left it with you and her—I did not leave you in Brick-lane—Long-alley is down Com
mercial-street—one of Davis's statements was that he had been asleep in a coffee-house till past two o'clock.

WILLIAM KING (policeman, A 416.) On Saturday morning, 24th Feb., I met the prosecutor at the corner of Wentworth-street, in consequence of what he said to me we went to George-street; we saw M'Carthy—he said, "This is one of the parties that has been robbing me"—I took her into custody, and while doing so, Davis came and said to the prosecutor, "You must be mis
taken in this female, she has been in my company till within these few minutes"—the prosecutor then said, "This is one of the men who assisted in robbing me"—he had not before that given me any description of Davis but he then said there were two men, and one of the men had got a scar on his cheek, and after I got away to the light, I found Davis had got a scar on his cheek—the prosecutor had been drinking, but he knew what he was about; he talked reasonably.

Cross-examined. Q. You saw he had been drinking? A. Yes; I have been over to the other side of the water; I do not know what business a man has in Whitechapel to go from Lambeth to Long Alley—it may be a mile out of his way—M'Carthy was standing openly at a door—I had not seen her there before.
M'Carthy. Q. Was there not an officer who came and said I could not he the woman? A. He said he had seen you at your door; his name was Frost—he is now dismissed from the service.

SAMUEL GRBEN (policeman, H 61). I took Wood into custody in a room which she occupies in Keate-street, Spitalfields—I found this common watch-key in a pail of dirty suds in the room—I took her between one and two o'clock in the morning, within half an hour or three-quarters of an hour of the robbery.

Wood. Q. You saw me with the prosecutor; were either of these prisoners with me then? A. No; the prosecutor called me by name, and I told him he had better go home—you went up Brick-lane with him to get some more drink, and in ten minutes, or a quarter of an hour, I heard of the robbery, and went after you—Davis said he had been to the coffee-house—I went there,
and found he had been there, and had gone out to buy some tobacco about a quarter-past one o'clock.

JOHN BYLAND
re-examined. This is the key I lost—it is a miscast, and has a mark on it—I am certain of it; M'Carthy had a bonnet and shawl on when she was with me.

The prisoner Wood's statement before the Magistrate was read as follows: " The key the policeman found in my room has been there ever since I occupied the room; I was in the man's company, and drank with him in a public-house; there were only our two selves there; he treated the waiter to a glass of ale; he left with me, and was going home with me; he was going down the street, and then he said he would not go home, but if I liked to hare any more to drink I might."
M'Carthy's Defence. I was standing at my own door, between one and two o'clock, and the officer came and took me.

WILLIAM KINO
re-examined. M'Carthy had no bonnet and shawl on at the door—it was not so light at the place where I took Davis that the prose
cutor could see the scar in his face—there was not light enough to see it till I brought him to the gas lamp Witness for the Defence.

WILLIAM THOMPSON . I was at the Britannia coffee-house, and saw Davis come in, about five minutes past eleven, and about a quarter-past two, be went out to buy some tobacco; he did not come back again; he got into custody; he was not out before he went to get the tobacco.

cross-examined by MR. CAARTEEN. Q. What are you? A. A journeyman carpenter and joiner—I have worked for Mr. Burton, in Finsbury-square, for four months—I know the prisoner by seeing him in the coffee-house several times—there was another young man sitting in the next box to when I was; I cannot say who he was; there was only the waiter there that I know of the whole evening—the waiter has been here several days; he is not here to-day—I noticed the time when Davis came in, and it was a quarterp-ast two o'clock when he went out—the waiter came and awoke him up, and asked him for a pipe of tobacco—he said he had none, he would go and get some—I had no object in noticing the time—I do not notice the time when every one comes in.

COURT. Q. What was he doing in the coffee-house? A. He came in there and had a cup of coffee, and as soon as he had had it he fell asleep—I am not aware that the waiter said it was a quarter-past one o'clock when he left.

SAMUEL OREEN
re-examined. I went to the waiter at the coffee-shop about half-past two—the waiter said he went out at a quarter-past one—the coffee-shop is about three hundred yards from George-street.

WILLIAM KINO
re-examined. Not two minutes elapsed from the time of the robbery to my taking M'Carthy into custody.

DANIEL SUGGS (police-sergeant, H 17). I produce a certificate of Davis's former conviction at Clerkenwell—read—"Convicted May, 1842, and confined six months, six weeks of the time solitary"—he is the man.

DAVIS—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

M'CARTHY—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

WOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 24

1004.
JOHN HOLMES and
RICHARD WILLIAMS
, feloniously break
ing and entering the warehouse of
Henry Dymond, and stealing 237 pairs of boots and shoes, value 80l.; his property.
HENRY DYMOND . I am a vendor of boots and shoes—my warehouse is

at No. 2, Regent-street, City-road, in the parish of St. Luke's. At a quarter before six in the evening of 16th Feb., I left those premises safe—I was called up that night, went to my warehouse, and found the front door open, and two storeroom doors had been forced open—the bolt of the lock of the front door was turned back—it appeared to have been opened without violence—I missed upwards of 200 pairs of boots and shoes, worth from 80l. to 100l.—they were shown to me at the station by the police.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. What time did you leave the pre
mises? A. My workmen leave at half-past five o'clock, and we leave shortly afterwards—I went out that evening with the foreman and another man; and afterwards finding I had left something behind, I went back, opened the door and got it—I then came out and locked the door—I know of no keys not these, which I keep myself.
Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Was this a dark night? A. I do not recollect.

WILLIAM CLARK . I lived in Baldwin's-place, City-road, but I have removed—I am a coal-porter. On Friday evening, 16th Feb., I was at the Wenlock-tap—the potman drew my attention to a horse and cart standing at the Wenlock Arms—that was about eleven o'clock—there was no one in the cart—I went and got a light to look at the name on the cart, as I thought it was lost—when I brought the light, a man ran up and said, "It is all right," and he got into the cart and drove off—to the best of my belief the man had a flannel jacket on, and a cap—he turned round, and went down the street—I went into the house again—the young man told me afterwards that the cart had come back—I went and saw that it had come back—there was a man in it driving—I could not say whether it was the same man that I had seen before—I followed the cart into the Wharf-road, and I stopped there talking to a man whom I met—I saw the cart again by Mr. Dymond's warehouse-door—they were putting something in it—I afterwards watched it as it drove down the City-road—I followed it to Bath-street, just opposite Willow-walk—I saw a policeman in Old-street, and told him—I could not say whether there were two, three, or four persons in the cart—I was behind the police
man, he stopped the cart—the persons in it immediately jumped out and ran away in different directions—I did not run after them, but stopped with the cart—I saw Holmes brought back by the policeman—I did not see the man in the flannel jacket sufficiently to know who he was—it was dark—I could not swear to the man—I have no belief as to who that person was—(looking at his deposition) this is my signature—I could not read this writing without I looked over it a good bit—this was not read over to me when I signed it—they asked me to put my name to it—I did not understand what it was for, nor what it was about—I knew it was about the hearing of these men, and then they asked me to put my name down, and I did—I said at Worship-street I thought Williams was the man in the flannel jacket and cap, but then he had a flannel jacket and cap put on—I said I thought he looked like the man, but I could not swear to him—I do not recollect saying he was the man before I saw him in the flannel jacket and cap—when they put the flannel jacket and cap on I said he was something like the man, I could not swear to him—to the best of my belief the person I did see had a flannel jacket and cap, but it was dark, I could not swear to it—it was a dirty flannel jacket—I cannot say whether the man in the flannel jacket and cap jumped out of the cart, I said I believed so—when I first saw the man in the flannel jacket had blown the light out—he came up before I had seen the name on the cart—whether the candle was out I cannot say.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How near were you to the cart when it was at the prosecutor's door? A. About fifty yards from it—it did not come towards me, it turned round—I cannot say how many persons were in the cart when it was at the door—I passed by it on the other side of the way.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLBSTON. Q. Was it not dark? A. It was—I was at some distance—when I was before the Magistrate I expressed some doubt about the man, and they put a flannel jacket and cap on him, that was while my evidence was being taken—I could not see whether there were two, three, or four men in the cart—it was a dark night, and the prosecutor's premises are in a very dark part of the street—I never saw Williams in my life before.

MR. PARRY. Q. Was the jacket put on while you were giving your evidence? A. I believe I had given my evidence before they put it on-then they put the jacket on to see whether I knew whether it was the man or not.

GEORGE GOODWIN . I am potman at the Wenlock tap—I know Clark—I remember on that Friday night calling his attention to a cart standing at the Wenlock tap—there was no one by it then—Clark went for a candle, and I went out with him, and at that time I saw a person standing by the side of the cart—he was very much like Williams, he was dressed in a flannel jacket and close cap—to the best of my belief it is him—I had not known him before.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Were you examined before the Magistrate? A. Yes—I did not see much of the man's features—they ordered Williams to put on the jacket and cap before me—I saw the man by myself first, and then I came out with Clark, with a candle—I cannot swear whether the candle was blown out or not—I had not a full view of the man's face—I saw him twice that evening; to the best of my belief he is the man.
MR. PARRY. Q. Did you see his side-face? A. I saw him sideways—from the observation I took of him, Williams resembles the man, but it was not a very light night.

JAMES MEAGER (policeman, N 234). At a quarter past eleven o'clock, on Friday night, 16th Feb., I was on duty in Old-street—Clark pointed out a cart to me, twenty or thirty yards off; there were three men in it—I fol
lowed it, and called out to them to stop—the driver was dressed in a scull cap, and a white flannel jacket; I have no belief as to who he was—I got up to the horse's head, and seized the reins, and stopped the cart—the persons who were in it jumped out, and ran away—I cannot say whether the cap and jacket now produced are what the man had on; it was a cap and jacket of this description—the persons who jumped out ran in the same direction as far as Willow-street—two of them turned down there, and Holmes kept on a-head—I followed, and took him into custody—I never lost sight of him from the time he jumped out of the cart; I am confident he is one of the men—he was stopped by Baker—I told him he was one of the men that jumped out of the cart—he said he was not—he appeared as if he had been running; he was very much excited and agitated—Clark minded the cart and horse while I was running—I found in the cart sixty-six pairs of Wellington boots, and 170 pairs of women's boots, and two pairs of shoes, and three crowbars—the name of "Richard Williams, Turk-street, Bethnal-green," was on the cart; it was then about twenty minutes past eleven—when I first took them it was about a quarter-past eleven—I afterwards went with Ball and Smith to Turk-street, Bethnal-green, about one—Williams would have had abundance of time to get home, supposing he had been the

person who jumped out of the cart—he is a marine-store dealer—Ball and Smith searched the house—it is about three-quarters of a mile from where I found the cart—I took the articles in the cart to the station—the prose
cutor identified them.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How far had Holmes run before you got him? A. About 200 yards; it might have been between 200 and 300 yards—I stopped the cart at the corner of Willow-walk—Holmes was apprehended within a few yards of Leonard-square—I was between twenty and thirty yards behind him—he had no turnings to take before I came to him; it was in a direct line—I swear he did not run down Willow-walk; the other two men did; he ran straight a-head down Paul-street; he was in Paul-street, at the corner of Leonard-square, when he was apprehended.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Had you seen Clark before you stopped the cart? A. Yes; I then went and got hold of the head of the horse; the men were driving pretty fast, between five and six miles an how—I do not suppose I was running by the side of the cart above half a minute; it was a starlight night, but a little hazy.

GEORGE BAKER (policeman, G 228). On 16th Feb., about ten minutes past eleven o'clock, I was on duty in Leonard-square—I heard a cry of "Stop thief!" and saw Holmes running towards me—I stopped him—he asked me what I was stopping him for—I told him I would tell him presently—Meager, who was following him, came up, and said, "Bring him back," and we took him back into custody to the cart, which was standing at the end of Bath-street, opposite Willow-walk.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Could you see down Paul-street from the cart? A. I cannot say exactly whether I could or not—I was in Leonard-street, which runs across the square—I stopped Holmes in Paul-street.

WILLIAM EDWARD BALL (police-sergeant, N 54). Between twelve and one o'clock on the night of 16th Feb., I had information of this robbery—I went with Smith and Meager to 6, Turk-street, Bethnal-green, where Wil
