liams lives—it is a coal-shed at the back, and a marine-store shop in front—there were three lights; one was burning in the shed, and another in the back-room—I tapped at the window, and heard a scuffling noise inside—Williams put his head out of the bed-room window and said, "What is it?"—I said, "Is that you, Williams? is the horse come home?"—he said, "No; have you been after anything?"—I was in plain clothes—I asked him to come down, and he came and opened the front door, and said, "There you be"—I told him we were two police-constables, and we should take him into custody for a robbery in the City-road—he was undressed—he had neither trowsers or drawers on, and I observed he was rather excited—I said I should take him into custody for being concerned with others in a robbery in the City-road—he said, "Robbery, I know nothing of any robbery; a man came and borrowed my horse and cart; I suspected something was wrong, and I sent my boy to watch him, and he came back and told me that he had lost him somewhere near Mile-end-road"—I asked him who the man was that hired his cart—he said, "I do not know him; he was a short man, and dressed in a light jacket"—he said he would do his best endeavours to identify him—I told him to dress himself—he did so, and we went to the station—he said the man wanted the cart to remove some goods out of Thomas-street—I had partly searched his house—I went back again and asked his wife for her husband's jacket, and she gave me this jacket now produced—this cap was given to Smith the next day—I found a coat, and a quantity of new metal, which is not here—I went again the next morning—I
found a piece of silk-velvet and some handkerchiefs in a cupboard in the back room.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Have you told us all that took place? A. Perhaps not—I have to the best of my recollection-"I think when he said he would do his best endeavours to identify the man, that he said he wished he could see him—I think those words were mentioned—his wife gave me this jacket from a cupboard in the front room—that was after he was in custody—when I took him he did not put the cap on to go out, and I did not tell him to put his hat on—I noticed a cap in the room; I forget where it was—he did not put it on—something took place in the room about one of the men wearing a cap and a pilot coat—I did not tell him when he was going away to put his hat on—I remember now his saying that he would put on his hat—this was in the back room, the bed-room—I saw his cap there—he went in this pilot coat and hat.

JOHN SMITH (policeman, AT 121). I went with Baker to Williams's house on that evening—when he tapped at the window I heard a noise inside as of some persons moving about—Williams opened the window and said, "Who it there?"—Baker said, "Is that you, Williams: is the horse come home?" Williams said, "No"—Baker said, "Come down, I want to speak to you"—he came down and opened the front door—he had either trowsers or drawers on—he appeared flurried—Baker said he was taken into custody for a robbery in the City-road—he said, "Robbery, I know of no robbery"—Baker said, "For a robbery in Regent-street, City-road; your horse and cart is at the station"—he said, "I lent my horse and cart to a short dark man, dressed in a cap and light jacket"—Baker said, "Do you know who he is?"—he said, No; I should be very glad to identify him if you take him"—he said after the man was gone he had his misgivings, and sent the boy after him—I saw this flannel jacket found—this cap was given to me the next morning by Williams's wife.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Do you know anything of 5l. reward? A. The first bill I saw was sticking outside the station—I do not recollect that Williams took up his cap to put on, and that Baker said, "Take your hat, and not your cap"—I believe the word "hat" was mentioned by Baker, but what I do not know.

HOLMES—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Ten Years.

WILLIAMS—
NOT GUILTY .

1005.
EDWARD STANNARD
, unlawfully pledging and converting to his own use 15 securities, value 100l.; the property of
William Walker, which were entrusted to him for a special purpose.

WILLIAM WALKER . I am a clerk, living in Charlotte-street, Fitsroy-square. On 24th July I saw an advertisement in the Times newspaper, that a young man of respectability was wanted as clerk, to fill a mercantile situ
ation, at a salary of 70l. per annum, and that good security was required to the amount of 100l.—In consequence of that, I sent a letter to the address stated, and got an answer, which I have lost—in consequence of that answer, I went to 3, Pancras-lane—I saw over the door, "Edward Stannard, wine
merchant"—I saw the prisoner—I told him I had called respecting the adver
tisement, and my note was produced—he said he liked the appearance of the writing, and he thought I should suit him—he asked if I was a married man, as the salary was so small—I said, no, I was not, but I was in hopes it

might lead to something better eventually—I had stated in my letter that I had been engaged on the London and Brighton Railway, and gave him a reference to Mr. Buckland, the secretary—he said he would write to him, and he made an appointment for Thursday, 27th July—I called on that day—he said he had had a very pretty note from Mr. Buckland, and was perfectly satisfied—I had stated that, if it were necessary, I could lodge railway shares to the amount of 100l.—the shares I had were of the Reading, Reigate, and Guildford Railway—on 27th July the prisoner said he knew nothing of rail
way shares—I told him the security was equal to money—(the shares were what they call guarantee stock)—he made an appointment for me on the following Monday, and I was to take my shares with me, but I forgot them, and I was to bring them on the following Monday—he gave me two or three cards, and said I was to present them to my friends—this is one of them—I went on the following Monday, and entered on my business—I am not certain, but I think I was sent down to the Docks to inquire if certain vessels had arrived—I think one of the ships did come in, but there was nothing in it for him—I did not see any wines in wood or bottles on his premises—I took my shares to him on the 9th of Aug.—I could have got 100l. for them, or perhaps a pound or two more at the market price—they are negotiable by transfer—I gave them to the prisoner as security for integrity—he had no authority whatever to dispose of them, or to raise money on them—I conti
nued as his clerk for three weeks—I never saw any wines bought or sold—on the 29th Aug. I went to the warehouse as usual, and I found a van at the door, with empty bottles and hampers—I went down into the cellar, and there was not the slightest appearance of any wine having been there—I stopped the van, and went to Mr. Exley's—on my return home I found this letter, by post, in the prisoner's writing—he did not call on me again—I went to Mr. Exley's office, and saw the prisoner there—he had given me an I O U about a week before, and he offered to meet me at Mr. Exley's—I never got my shares back—I had before ascertained from the prisoner that they were in the hands of Mr. Exley—the prisoner got me to sign a memorandum—he pressed me very much to allow him a week to settle the matter, and after a little con
sideration I consented—his wife was there, and she importuned me as well—that was on the Monday, I believe, and on the Wednesday I was to meet him at Mr. Exley's, and he was to arrange with Mr. Exley that the shares were to be given up to me—on the 9th Sept. I was to have 9l., for salary given up to me, and on this consideration I said I would not take any pro
ceedings against him—I never got my shares, nor the 9l., salary—I do not know what became of the prisoner, I lost sight of him then.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. My friend put into your mouth that the prisoner got you to sign a document; how old are you? A. Thirty-six—I knew what I was signing, but it was only to be in existence for a week—I knew that I was promising to take no proceedings against him, and if I had received my money and shares I would not—I took proceedings against him about a month ago—I left nearly five months pass—I had not had any communication with him during that time—I met him in Dec. in Mr. Exley's office—I did not tell him that if he would give up the shares that would satisfy me—I had gone to Mr. Exley's that day for the purpose of coming to some arrangement with Mr. Exley—I said, if I possibly could, I would call the next day—I did not, but a friend of mine did.
JOHN EXLEY . I am a corn-factor, at 75, Mark-lane. I did not purchase fifteen shares of the Reading, Reigate, and Guildford Railway Company of

the prisoner, but I received twelve shares of him on 12th Aug., and three on the 19th—he gave me this memorandum on 12th Aug.—the body of it is my writing, the signature is his—he acknowledges the receipt of 20l., and authorizes me to sell the shares within three weeks, if the money was not retained—on 19th Aug. he gave me this memorandum, acknowledging the receipt of 30l., and authorizing me to sell the shares if the money was not returned—I had bought the goods and fixtures at 3, Pancras-lane, for about 18l.—I bought them of the landlord's brother, who had seized for rent—there was no stock of wine amongst the goods—I took a bill of sale of the broker, and left the prisoner in possession—the prisoner was insolvent in Feb., 1848—the goods which were upon the premises in Aug. were those for which I had taken a bill of sale in the previous Feb.—I removed them in Aug.—the landlord wished me to have them away—he wanted to have the house—the bill of sale I think was dated about 18th Feb.—he gave me the shares on the 12th and 19th Aug.—I gave him 20l. on the 12th, and 30l. on the 19th, making 50l. together, and he was a debtor to me before.

Cross-examined. Q. What does he owe you? A. About 180l.—I could not take these shares without advancing him money, because he would not give them up—he asked me for a loan on these, and agreed to allow 5l. when the shares were sold, to go off the old account—he gave me permission to sell the shares if in three weeks he did not redeem them—I am willing to give up the shares now, if the advance is paid me—Mr. Walker brought, an action against me in Oct.
MR. BODKIN. Q. I believe you offered to give up your shares without the money? A. I did at the Mansion-house.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you willing to do so now? A. No—it was offered by the defendant to give me a Judge's order for the amount—he was willing to do it at that time—that was on 12th March.

JOSEPH MANN . I am a clerk. I became acquainted with the prisoner in June, 1847—I was in his service a short time—I remember his insolvency in 1848—I was a creditor of his to the amount of about 100l.—he was cleared by the Insolvent Court in March—there was no dividend paid—I have seen this circular about these wines—there was the same thing when I was with him—he was then in Pancrass-lane—he had no stock at that time—I occasionally went to the docks to taste wines—I was with him five months, and left him on 23d Nov., 1847.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you clerk to Mr. Stannard, or master, which? A. I was clerk—I saw an advertisement in the paper, which I suppose was his—I paid 100l. for integrity when I went in his service in June, 1847—I did not sketch this circular, not a line of it—I recommended a printer to him to print them—I knew it was a circular—I had seen it on his table, and knew the purport of it—I knew it was quite false—I did not take it to be printed—I procured him a printer.
MR. BODKIN. Q. What salary were you to have? A. To commence at 70l. a year, and to be raised to 100l.

SAMUEL JARMAN . I am clerk to Mr. Humphreys—I produce these docu
ments from the Insolvent Court—they are certified copies under the seal of the Court in the matter of Edward Stannard—one is the balance-sheet—the amount of debt is 1510l., and the other is the adjudication—on 17th March an order was made to discharge him from prison.

MR. BALLANTINE to WILLIAM WALKER. Q. I suppose you are aware that these shares cannot be made any use of till they are transferred by yourself? A. I am quite aware of that, not legally they cannot—I am deprived of the
power to dispose of them—I cannot get new ones delivered to me—I receive the dividends still, and I have paid a call on them since.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

1006.
JANE MATTHEWS
, stealing 200 sovereigns, 400 half-sovereigns, 400 crowns, 400 half-crowns, 400 shillings, and 400 sixpences; the moneys of
Henry Luard and others, in the dwelling-house of
Mary Ann Griffiths.

RICHARD HUMPHREYS . I am messenger to the London and County Bank in Lombard-street. On Monday, 12th March, I made up a parcel containing 200l. in gold, and 200l. in silver—Augustus Prime took the parcel—this is it.

AUGUSTUS PRIME . I am porter to the London and County Bank. On 12th March I took this parcel from the Bank to the Cross Keys, St. John-street—I delivered it to Jonathan Seymour, the coachman of the Bedford-coach.

JONATHAN SEYMOUR . I am the coachman of the Luton coach, which starts at five o'clock in the evening, from the Cross Keys, in St. John-street—I received this parcel from Prime on 12th March, about a quarter of an honr before the coach started—I put the parcel on a desk in the inner bar—Mrs. Griffith was in the outer bar—the prisoner was in the inner bar, sitting by the side of the fireplace—I left the parcel on the desk—I always put it there.

MARY ANN GRIFFITHS . I keep the Cross Keys, in St. John-street, Clerkenwell—it is my dwelling-house, and is in the parish of St. Sepulchre—the Luton coach goes from my house about five o'clock. On the 12th March I saw the coachman come with the parcel into the bar-room—I saw him put it on the desk, on the left-hand as you go into the room—the prisoner was in the bar at that time, sitting opposite the door, a little beyond the fire-place—I think I had spoken to her, but I am not quite certain—I was there when she first came, about twenty minutes before five o'clock—she had a shawl and bonnet on—she asked Miss Bishop some question, and went away—she returned, and after she had returned I saw her sitting in the bar-room when the coachman took the parcel to the desk—the door by which you enter from the bar to the bar-room is a glazed door—I remember a gentleman coming in in a very few minutes after the parcel came—I knew him by sight, he had been sometimes at the house—I did not know his name—I do not think he had anything in his hand—he went into the bar-room—I was inside the bar, and met him coming, before he got to the door which goes into the bar-room—I interposed to prevent his going into that room—he pushed rudely, by me, saying there was a lady there belonging to him—he then went by the glazed door into the bar-room, and went up to where the prisoner was sitting—there was a conversation between them—I heard nothing more than the word "wife," which was said by the prisoner—I was then standing near the desk on which the parcel was—I noticed that it was in its proper state, and done up in brown paper, sealed and directed—this is it—while I was standing near the desk, the gen
tleman called for a glass of sherry—I went towards the door, and asked Miss Bishop to bring it him—she brought it, and I gave it him—I was all the time remaining in the room—he gave me a shilling to pay for it, and I called to Miss Bishop to give 6d. change—in doing that I turned from the prisoner and the gentleman towards the glazed door, and I observed, reflected by the glass, the red seals of a parcel being passed by the gentleman across to the prisoner where she was sitting—the gentleman was then between the desk and the chair the prisoner was sitting on—I went to the desk, and there found a different parcel to the one that had been there—this is it—it is

sealed, but has no direction on it—I examined it so as to see that it was not the parcel that had been there before—I turned to the gentleman, and said, "You have changed the banker's parcel!"—I had the sham parcel then in my hand—on my saying that he took hold of my arm, and attempted to pot me out of the bar—I threw this parcel to Miss Bishop, and said, "Get assist
ance;" but he succeeded in pushing past me and leaving the house—I turned, and saw the parcel drop from the right side of the prisoner—I did not observe where it came from—she had then left the chair and approached the desk—she said, "What is all this about?"—she did not attempt to leave the room then—she had before approached the door, and I said to her, "If he has escaped, you shall not"—a gentleman named Elwin came to ray assist
ance, and she was detained—there was no other parcel on the desk but the banker's parcel—I had known the gentleman by sight—he had called to leave a coat, and sometimes had a glass of sherry when he fetched it away In the afternoon—there were two men in the house, whom I had noticed before when that gentleman was there—they were standing at the bar window—I believe they had some brandy-and-water—I did not serve them—I did not see anything more of them.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Ton only saw the parcel on the ground? A. I saw it sliding down by the side of the prisoner's dress—I am sure that is correct—I was very much flurried—when the man came in, he went up at once and spoke to the prisoner—her shawl had fallen from her shoulder, as I supposed, with the weight of the parcel.

ANN BISHOP . I assist Mrs. Griffiths in the business. On 12th March the prisoner came there from half-past four o'clock to twenty minutes before five—she asked what time the coach went, and asked to be allowed to sit down—she moved towards the inner bar—I told her that room was engaged, she could go into the coffee-room or up stairs—she said there were gentlemen in the coffee-room, and she expected a friend, she would walk out a little way—she went out, and came back—I then asked her to walk into the bar
parlour, and she did, and sat on a chair near the fire—I saw a gentleman come in—he said, "You have a lady here belonging to me"—that was said loud enough for the prisoner to hear—he pushed rudely by Mrs. Griffiths, and pushed into the room—I heard Mrs. Griffiths ask for a glass of sherry, which I gave her—she then gave me a shilling to give her sixpence change—the gentleman then pushed her, she threw the parcel to me, and he made his escape—she called for assistance, and Mr. Elwin came in—I had seen the gentleman several times before—he used to come in the morning, and ask me to take his coat—he never treated me with anything to drink—I saw two other men in the house, and on one occasion I had seen one of those men and the gentleman walking together in Old-street-road—those two men were at the house that day, and had brandy-and-water—when this took place, they said, "What is the matter?" and went away, leaving their brandy-and-water partly untouched, and not paid for.

REV. THOMAS HENEY ELWIN . I am a clergyman of East Barnet—I was at the Cross Keys waiting for the Luton coach—in consequence of some alarm I went to the bar, and saw Mrs. Griffiths—the prisoner was in the bar-room, and Mrs. Griffiths asked me to assist in detaining her, which I did—the policeman came, and she was taken into custody—she said, "Why am I detained?" and said they were in error.

ELIZABETH LICKFIELD . I keep a coffee-house, in Bridge-street, South
wark—I know the prisoner—she came to me in Feb.—she gave the name of Mrs. Matthews—she lodged three weeks with me.
WILLIAM M'KEWAN . I am accountant at the London and County Bank—Mr. Henry Luard is the general manager of the bank—he is a shareholder and there are others.

JOHN ARCHER (policeman, G 217). The prisoner was given into my custody for stealing the banker's parcel—she said, "Allow me to have a glass of sherry, or sherry and water"—I then told her she must come with me to this station—she said she was waiting for a Miss Brown, who was going by the coach to Barnet—I said we would wait till the coach started to see if she came we waited, and she did not—I then took the prisoner—I was present where she was taken before the Magistrate—she was asked her name, and she said we might give her any name we pleased, one name was as good as another—on the last examination she gave the name of Jane Matthews.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1007.
PATRICK CONNER
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Alfred Staniford, with intent to steal.
MR. PAYNE, JUN., conducted the Prosecution.

ALFRED STANIFORD . I am a publican, in George-street, Lisson-grove, St. Marylebone. On 1st April, at a quarter past three o'clock in the morning, I was awoke by my wife, who said she heard footsteps in the room—she jumped up, and I did the same—I looked all round, and saw the prisoner under the bed—I took hold of him and put him on the bed—I sent for a policeman, and he was taken into custody—he said, "I hope you will forgive me this time"—I said, "No, not if you were my own brother"—I knew him to be a hardworking man a year and a half ago.

JOHN MANNING (police-sergeant, D 44). I was called, and took the prisoner—he had his shoes off—I searched about the yard, and found a ladder against the washhouse—I went up the ladder, and found his shoes on the top of the washhouse—I asked him where his shoes were—he said he had lost them—when he came down he said they were on the tiles.

Prisoner's Defence. Having been keeping company with the servant, I went to the house for the purpose of seeing her, as I was going into the country the next day; and not wishing to disturb her master, and knowing that the window was left unfastened, I thought I would avail myself of it to get in to see her.

ALFRED STANIFORD
re-examined. I have no servant—my wife has a sister, but she never had a word with the prisoner—my window was shut at night, and it was open in the morning, when I found him.

GUILTY .—
Confined Nine Months.

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Ald. WILLIAM HUNTER; Mr. Ald. CARDEN; and EDWARD

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq., and the Fifth Jury.

div1.p:
1008.
RICHARD ORLANDO LEGG
, unlawfully assaulting
Peter James Legg on the high seas: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . And received a good character.—
Fined 20l.

1009.
JOHN BROWN
, unlawfully assaulting Elizabeth Sells, with intent,
NOT GUILTY .

1010.
JOHN COUPLAND
and
ELIZA COUPLAND
, unlawfully assaulting and beating
John William Coupland, aged five years, and neglect
ing to give him sufficient food. (See page 617.)
MESSRS. BODKIN, CLERK, and PLATT, conducted the Prosecution.

JANE SALTER . I am the wife of Henry Salter; in January, 1848, we lived at 7, Palace-row, New-road; the prisoners came to lodge there at the latter end of March, or beginning of April, 1846—the little girl was born there in the following October or November; a boy named John William came home; he was then about two years and a half old—he was a healthy nice child then; I have heard the parents very cruelly use it; the last time was when I was at the foot of the stairs, and heard the father violently beating it; the mother said something, and he said, "D—n its little eyes, I will beat its b—d belly in"—I heard it screaming, and heard him say, "I will knock its b----y brains out;" he then appeared to dash it against the wainscot—the mother was in the room—the child cried very much, and about ten minutes afterwards it came down stairs for a halfpe'th of milk; it was in a very bad state of crying, and seemed very trembling; he scarcely knew how to walk down stairs—he pulled up his clothes, and said, "Look here, Mrs. Salter, what my father has been doing." I looked at his legs, and from the bottom of the loins to the calf of the leg he was so emaciated, that the blood was raised to the surface of the skin; it was bruises—there were many other such occasions before that, the mother was always very cruel to it from the time it came home; scarcely a day passed but what it was bruised—it was in a very thin delicate state when it left in April, 1848; it was bruised from head to foot—I have given it food in consequence of the cruelty of its mother; the father was urged to beat it by the mother—the language used to be very shocking on both sides—the father used to be away for a month together; but for the last three months, scarcely a day passed without my hearing one of them beating the child.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. When did you leave your house? A. In the latter end of last April; the last occurrence I speak of was a week before they left, the father beat it then—I know that, by the violence of his hands—I did not go to prevent its being murdered, or send for an officer when I saw the marks on its person, I only complained to my lodgers and neighbours—I have talked to the mother on good terms and on bad terms—I do not think I ever saw the child free from bruises for the year and a half it was there—once it had a black eye, and bruises on the forehead at different times—I gave the prisoners notice to quit, as I was going to leave my house—they left the day before me—I do not owe half a year's rent—I gave the prisoner's warning several times, but they would not go—I have not been to any loan society—I believe Mrs. Coupland was sent, but it is a long time ago—my husband and Mr. Coupland were going to have the loan between them—I did not send any forged receipts to the society, and did not forge any—I think the security was not sufficient—I never went to tea with the prisoners—I went into the room when she was confined, and dressed her child—the boy was healthy and stout when he came, and he was healthy when he left, but very weak and emaciated.

MR. CLERK. Q. When you reasoned with her about her conduct to the child, what answer did she make? A. The answer generally used to be, "D—him I hate him, he is so much like his father's friends"—my hus
band has been paying the rent since we left—it is not all paid.
ELIZA REEVES . I am the wife of William Reeves, a shoemaker of

Somers-street, Hatton-garden—I knew the deceased child—it died about the 27th of January—I lived in the first-floor front—I have heard the male prisoner call the child a d----d young b—r and say he would knock its b----y guts out—I saw the child when it came down to the water-closet; it seemed so weak it could scarcely walk—it was usually kept locked in the front-room—I have seen the aunt throw bread in at the window when the parents were out—at the latter part of the time they altered to the back-room—I have heard a fall in the front-room when no one was there but the child and the prisoners, and have heard a scream immediately afterwards; it appeared in good health, but for the last two months it sunk rapidly—in November last, I heard a noise in the back kitchen like the child being choked; I went and saw the female prisoner polling it out of a tub of water—I had heard the noise three or four minutes before—about three mornings afterwards she put it in again, holding it by the feet with its head downwards; she kept it in about half a minute; it seemed almost suffocated—it was half a butter tub of cold water; she was scolding it, and said it had dirtied itself—I did not speak to her—I was afraid to interfere with her—the man was not there.
Cross-examined. Q. When was this? A. About three weeks before Christmas—I was never in their room—I never had a child—I have got my third husband.

WILLIAM REEVES . I am the husband of the last witness—we lived in Somers-street six or seven months before the child died—its name was John William Coupland—it was nearly five years old—I used frequently to see it—I occupy the front parlour, and it was generally kept in the room over my head, and generally alone—the mother used at times to run up; she would leave it for hours at a time; she used the girl as an angel compared with this child—the boy appeared wasting away for six months—the girl was not so by any means—Mrs. Parker, the aunt, who lives opposite, has frequently thrown bread up to the child—I have frequently heard the child screaming, and heard the father say he would stamp his guts out, and then I have heard the child being beat, and thrown down—that would happen frequently—I was not away from home from morning to night
Cross-examined. Q. You have never had any children? A. Not by this wife, but by my former wife—I am the rather of nineteen, but only two are living.

MART CAVANNAGH . I am the wife of Edward Cavannagh. Last Jan. we lived in the parlour at 8, Somers-street—we were there two months—the pri
soners lived in the room above us—the child died there—I have seen it come down—it was in a very bad state, much declined—about five weeks before the inquest I noticed that its face was black from the forehead to the chin—I went to ask it a question, but the mother put her head out at the window, and it did not answer me—I have heard the mother lock it in, and go out without him, and when she has come in I have heard a noise as if the child was beaten, and knocked against the floor—I asked her what was the matter with him—she said he was perfectly well, but it was his own bad temper and dirt left him in the state he was in—the other child was very healthy, and was treated very well, as far as I could see.
Cross-examined. Q. You were never in the room? A. No, only when the child was burnt.

JAMES WRIGHT . I am a surgeon, and lived at Wardour-street, Clerken
well, at the time of the accident. I saw the child on 26th Jan., in a state of insensibility, and in a very reduced, emaciated state, apparently for want of food—he called for bread and butter, and ate it most voraciously, so that it

quite astonished me—the bread and butter was in the room—I asked the pri
soners a few questions, and they told me they had been in a state of great destitution for upwards of twelve months—I said the child must have nourish
ment—they said they had not the means of getting it—I said if they came to my house they should have a small piece of mutton—the mother went with me for it—I was called next morning, and found the child burnt.

Cross-examined. Q. They sent for you on that occasion? A. Yes; I found them waiting for me—the mother was very far advanced in pregnancy, and has been delivered in gaol—the whole place presented a scene of destitu
tion, but I have witnessed many worse—they had furniture, and bread and butter—she was very thankful to me for the mutton—I found it on the fire next day—she told me they were in a horrible state of starvation—I offered to attend her—a child having mesenteric disease gets emaciated, and very frequently the lungs get diseased—consumptive people get thin—I did not know the child had disease of the lungs till the post mortem examination, at which I was not present—the mother seemed as intent and anxious as mothers usually are—I have seen the girl in the street—she was very healthy—I know that consumptive people eat voraciously.

THOMAS JACKMAN . I am house-surgeon to St. Bartholomew's Hospital. The child was brought there on 27th Jan.—I made a post mortem examination—the cause of death was a burn—the body was in a very emaciated state; the lungs were affected with inflammation of the lower lobes to a considerable extent, otherwise the child was healthy; there were some recent bruises on the head and legs—there was a bruise on both eyebrows, which could not be produced by a child falling on the floor—there were about three bruises on each leg, corresponding with each other, as if the two legs were struck at the tame time—there was no disease about the child to account for the emaciated state in which I found it.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been admitted as a surgeon? A. About twelve months—I pay for my place at the hospital, I have no salary—I cannot always tell by inspection what disease has or has not existed.

MRS. PARKER. I am the female prisoner's aunt, and have known the child from its birth—it has always been a very ailing child, and was in the country with its grandmother more than a year—it returned to town, and I saw it almost every day till its death—I lived right opposite, and have done so twenty-one years—I never saw the father or mother illtreat it in my life—I never saw any marks on his person—the parents have been in a great state of want, but they treated him as well as their circumstances would admit—they have been in a state of starvation—I have known them to breakfast on 2d. a morning for the last two months: half an ounce of coffee, half an ounce of sugar, and a pennyworth of bread, and I have given them firing to do it with—I have known them to be from Monday to Wednesday without fire or food, she and her two children, when he has been out butchering with Mr. Bamford, but he has had nothing to do since Feb. or March last—I recol
lect the child being taken to the hospital; the mother carried it—it never complained of its mother's treatment; it wanted to go home to her at the hospital—I once threw a bit of bread in at the window to it, and many times I have thrown to it a bit of sweet-stuff, or gingerbread, or an apple when I have seen it at the window, and he has come down to the door and I have given him something for himself, and his sister too; both when the mother was at home and when she was out; but she never was out much, only when she was nursing her sister—she was an attentive kind mother—she has been

with me in my confinement, and with my husband when he was ill, and three of my children she brought up, and I never knew a bad thing of her in my life—she was a servant before her marriage, and was seven years in one street, and respected and beloved by every one who knew her—if she saw a poor creature in the street she would give them something.

Cross-examined by MR. CLERK. Q. How was it that you threw the things up at the window? A. Because I saw him at the window—the room-door used not to be locked until the latter part of the time, when they thought a broker would be put in for rent, and then Mrs. Coupland used to go back
wards and forwards to the child—sometimes she left the girl with me in the morning; the boy was locked up by himself at times, not for five hours together, it might be an hour or an hour and a half—I produce a quantity of tickets of things which they have pledged—the father could get nothing to do—he did not supply Mr. Bamford with meat, sometimes not one day in the week, because she would ask me to lend her money to get Mr. Bamford some meat—I have advised her to apply for relief, and a lady living by, gave her a Philanthropic ticket, and I went to a lady in Hatton-garden to get coals and bread—I know Mrs. Coningsbee; I do not recollect her saying something to which I replied that I had thrown the child up some bread and a turnip to quench his thirst, but that if she interfered the mother would scratch her eyes out, she was such a wretch—I never threw a turnip into the room—I saw the child at the hospital, but did not see any bruises on it.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did the mother go to the hospital? A. Yes; and she would have gone again at night, but I prevented her, as her pregnancy would not admit of it, but she went next morning at half-past five; I called her up.

SARAH ANN DAY . I am the female prisoner's sister, and live with my mother in Cambridgeshire. The child was with her some time—it was wry ill, it scarcely enjoyed a week's health during the eighteen months it was there—it never was strong—the mother's conduct to it was very kind indeed, and the father's also—I have visited them in town since the child came up, it still continued unhealthy.

Cross-examined by MR. CLERK. Q. Were you living with your grand-mother? A. Most of the time; I was in service six or seven months—I believe I saw the child the day before it left its grandmother; it was very unhealthy then—my mother had a doctor's bill of 16s. to pay when it left—I was not at Mrs. Salter's while they lived there—I have not been in Somers-street above once.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did you see the child while you were in service? A. Yes; it came to me several times, and I always found it unhealthy.

LYDIA ASHTON . I am the sister of the female prisoner, and live at 2, Red Lion-passage, Holborn, a quarter of a mile from Somers-street, I frequently saw the child—ray sister was always very kind to it, and her husband also—it was always very delicate and weak—the mother's conduct at the hospital was very kind and attentive—I have given them money several times to support them, and produce duplicates of their pawned property.
Cross-examined. Q. How often have you been to the house? A. Two or three times a week, before and since Christmas—I saw no bruises on the child at the hospital.

SARAH TICKTUM . I attended the woman in her confinement, at the birth of the child in question, until her mother came from the country—I always found her most affectionate towards it—I have known her eleven or twelve years—the child was always very pale, sickly and delicate from its birth—I
was only there as a friend, not as a nurse—I have not been bribed to come here—the man has always been kind and affectionate to her and the children.

Cross-examined. Q. Where do you live? A. 15, Rathbone place, Ox
ford-street—I have known her ten or eleven years—I have not seen her so much lately as formerly—I did not visit them at Somers-street or at Mrs. Suiters, the mother has called on me and brought the child with her, but not lately; it was more than six months ago—she behaved very kindly to it,

MR. HODSON. I am a licensed-victualler, of Great Warner-street, Clerken
well. I knew the female prisoner before she was married—she lived with Dr. Coombe, of Caroline-street—I have known her up to this time, ten or eleven years—she has always borne the character of a kind, affectionate, well-disposed woman—she has been in the habit of calling on me the whole of that time, more or less—I have lived in her neighbourhood for the last two years, and have seen her once or twice a week.
Cross-examined. Q. Where used you to see her? A. At my residence in Great Warner-street.

JOHN COUPLAND. Aged 29.
GUILTY of an Assault.

ELIZA COUPLAND. Aged 35,
Confined Six Months.

1011.
JOHN EATON and
CAROLINE EATON
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Purslow, and stealing therein 86 yards of cloth, 2 coats, and 16 waistcoat-pieces, value 28 l. 16s., his goods. MR. COOPER conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH PURSLOW . I am the wife of John Purslow, a tailor, of 6, Upper King-street, Bloomsbury. On the night of 22d Feb., I fastened up the shop—I saw the shop-door last at eight o'clock next morning—about twenty-five minutes past eight my daughter called me—I found the shop open and everything taken from the counter.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had not you opened the shop door that morning? A. No, I found it open about ten minutes after I came down—the shutters were not taken down—my husband was up-stairs—he is not here—the property has not been traced.

SARAH PURSLOW . I am the daughter of the last witness. On 23d Feb., about half-past eight, I opened the passage-door and saw the female prisoner—site asked if my father Wanted a waistcoat-maker—I went up to ask him, came down, and told her "No"—she said, "Thank you," and shut the door—she looked very stout, and part of her gown was spread over the handle of the door—in about five minutes I found the door wide open, and called my mother down.
Cross-examined. Q. When you saw a stout woman at Marylebone, did you say you knew her by her bonnet and breast? A. Yes; I had a good view of her face, and am quite sure she is the party.

WILLIAM HARRIES . I am a sawyer. On 23d Feb., about half-past eight, I was taking down my shutters, and saw the male prisoner coming out of Mr. Purslow's shop with a bundle of clothes, and give it to a woman under an archway—I could see two rolls of cloth, and part of a coat—I followed them as far as Orange-street.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen the man before? A. No, but I cannot be mistaken in him—I did not tell Mr. Purslow—I thought they were parties who worked for him—I did not notice his eye—the right side of his lace was to me—(prisoner's left eye was injured).
MICIAIH REED (policeman, E 108). On 16th March, Miss Purslow pointed out the female to me in Great Marylebone-street—I told her the

charge; she said she was innocent, that she lived at 49, Lowman's-hill, West
minster—I found there was no such number—I afterwards went to 30, Tot
tenham-street, and found this piece of iron, which she said she used to roast her meat with—it is used as a pick-lock—(The prisoner Caroline being taken in labour, Mr. Cooper consented to a verdict of
NOT GUILTY
with respect to her.)

JOHN EATON—
GUILTY .

1012.
JOHN EATON was again indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Henry Eld, and stealing 54 pairs of boots, value 25l., and 1 pair of shoes, value 3s.; the goods of
James Towers,

WILLIAM HENRY ELD . I am an appraiser, of 28, Denmark-street, in the parish of St. Giles's-in-the-Fields. I let the shop to Mr. Towers—on 8th March, between half-past ten and eleven at night, I went to bed—the house was fast; you cannot get into the shop without coming through my pri
vate door
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You were not the last person up? A. The lodgers might be up.

GEORGE GODDEN (policeman, F 128). On 8th March, about half-past twelve at night. I found Mr. Eld's door ajar; it was fast when I went my round about twelve—I went into the passage and called the landlord up—as he came down stairs the prisoner and two others rushed out of the shop—I caught hold of the prisoner and another—they all three struck me on the head and dragged me into the street—the prisoner fell down; he got up, and ran away—I never lost sight of him—I took him to the station—the other two escaped.

Cross-examined. Q. Where is the shop-door? A. At the corner of the street, but it shuts up with shutters, no one can get in there; the other door is two or three yards in the passage—I took the prisoner about a hundred yards from the house, and am sure of him—he turned a corner, but I did not lose sight of him—he was stopped—I was not six yards behind him.
JOHN HOBBS FROST (policeman, F 23). I heard a cry of "Stop thief!"—I saw the prisoner coming as hard as he could—I stopped him—he said that was all he got for doing police duty.
Cross-examined. Q. Where was Godden? A. Six or seven yards behind.

JOSEPH BARFIELD . I lodged with Mr. Eld. On 9th of March, between twelve and one o'clock in the morning my dog barked; I went down and found a policeman in the passage—I said, "What do you want?" and before he could answer, three men rushed out—the prisoner was the third; he struggled with Godden—they both fell in the passage, and again in the street—the prisoner ran, and Godden after him—I picked up a hat where the prisoner fell, and took it to the station—he said, "That is my hat, give it to me"—I returned to the house and found a bag full of boots with the mouth to the ground, with another bag laid over it, and a pile of boots beside it, a key and padlock lay on the desk.
Cross-examined. Q. Does not the door open toward the stairs? A. Yes; but I could see—I had past it before they came out—the prisoner struck me in the face.

JOHN GIBBS (policeman, F 158). On this morning I went to Mr. Eld. I saw a bag of boots and shoes in the shop, and another empty on it—I pro
duce this padlock and two keys; one key was in the door, it must have fitted by a person acquainted with the house.
WILLIAM GUMMER . I am shopman to James Towers; I left the back shop-door fastened with a padlock and common lock—the front door was fastened—I

do not know either of these keys—the boots and shoes were all in their places when I left—the prisoner had come to the shop before that with a female, and bought a pair of ladies boots—a man was outside the shop, who appeared to be waiting for them—the prisoner asked to go backwards—he was gone about a second—the padlock was not in the door then, but the staple was—he passed the door.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not Mr. Towers say, any stranger could make a key to fit the padlock, and he suspected you? A. Yes; I was at home that night, at 14, Stacey-street—I take the keys with me—I bring the boots in from the door, and put them on the floor at night.
MR. COOPER. Q. You had no hand in making these keys? A. No, I never saw them before.

GUILTY .* Aged 32.—
Transported for Ten Years.

div0.p: PRESENT—Mr. Ald. GIBBS and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the First Jury.

div1.p:
1103.
WILLIAM WOOD
, stealing 1 pawnbroker's ticket, value 25s.; and 1 pocket-book, 1d.; the property of
James Adams: having been before convicted.

JAMES ADAMS . I am ostler to Mr. Scott. On 11th of December, about eleven o'clock at night, I hung my jacket in the stable with a pocket-book in it, containing a ticket for a silver watch; the prisoner came there that day and asked me to give him some work—on the 18th I missed my pocket-book and ticket; these are them (prpduced)—I found them at the station.
Crbss-examined by Mr. PAYNE. Q. It was on Saturday night you saw them safe? A. Yes; I end not see the jacket again till Monday; I then missed them—there are two stables.
GEORGE FATHERS (policeman). I took the prisoner on 11th December, at the House of Correction, and found this pocket-book and duplicate in his possession.
JOHN DAFTER (policeman). The prisoner told me at the station-house, that if I could make it up he would give a sovereign.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not he tell you before that, that he found the pocket-book and duplicate? A. Yes.
JAMES BADWICK (policeman). I produce a certificate (read—William Wood, convicted Feb., 1848; confined three months)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY .* Aged 29.—
Confined One Year.

1014.
WILLIAM JONES and
JOHN DUNCAN
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Morrisson, at Islington, with intent to steal. MR. EWART conducted the Prosecution.

MARY ANN MORRISSON . I am the daughter of Mrs. Mary Morrisson, of 39, Suffolk-street, Lower-road, Islington. On 30th of March, I and my mother went on a visit, and shut the house up; we went to it on the Friday following, 3d of April, and found the kitchen window broken, the shutters forced in, and the sash down.

WILLIAM JOHN HALL . I am an engraver of 14, Suffolk-street. On 3d of April, between one and two in the morning, I saw Mrs. Morrisson's gate open—I went to the back-parlour window, and fancied I heard voices—I went to the door and waited till a policeman passed—he went with me to the back
of the house, and saw the window open, and found the prisoners by the wall—the policeman took them.

Crass-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did not Jones say he was intoxi
cated? A. Yes; there is a turning by the house—you can get over the wall easy enough.

WILLIAM ACASON (policeman, 423 N). Hall spoke to me—I went with him into his garden—the window-sash next door was open—the prisoners were standing close by the back kitchen—I took them in charge—Jones said they had had too much to drink—Duncan attempted to pass me—I found this life-preserver on him—I got assistance, and they were both taken.

THOMAS GOODSRHAM (policeman, N 433). I heard a rattle spring, and went to 13, Suffolk-street, and found the prisoners in Acason's custody—I re
ceived Jones—I saw Duncan throw away this jemmy—a knife, and some lucifers were found on Jones—Duncan said, "If they send me to Hobart Town, I can't be worse off for I have done nothing lately, and I meant to do it to-night, but you have spoilt it"—I found five marks on the kitchen door.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you pick up the jemm? A. Inside the railing of No. 14, about twelve yards from where Duncan stood, but he had been within half a yard of that place—it was dark—I saw him -fidgeting something in his band before he threw it—this is not the first time I have said that Duncan used the words, "You have spoilt it;" but I will not be positive as to those words (the witness's deposition being read, did not contain those words)—I told the Magistrate so.
JOHN BARTRON (policeman, N 65). I went to the premises—I saw the prisoner Duncan throw away these skeleton keys (produced)—the kitchen window was broken.
ELIZABETH WBLCH . I am a widow. On 3d of April, about halt-past eight o'clock, I was at No. 18; the kitchen window was safe, and the shutters bolted. MR. HORRY called

ROBERT LEAD . I am a hair-dresser, of 66, Long-lane, West Smithfield; Jones has lodged at my house eight or nine months—I recollect the morning he was taken—the night before, he went out at eleven o'clock, very drunk; he said he would not go to bed, he would try to walk it off—he took out some lucifers to light his pipe—he always carried them, being a very great smoker—I knew him three or four months before he came to me—his character has always been honest—I never knew anything to the contrary.

Cross-examined by MR. EWART. Q. What do you call very drunk.? A. When I went up he was asleep by the fire, with his head hanging over, as if he was going to be sick—I wanted to go to bed, and tried to rouse him—he has been a cellurman at a public-house close by—I never knew him to be out after twelve o'clock at night—it is generally half-past ten or eleven—I have had a son convicted—I have five sons,

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

DUNCAN—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

(John Robert Foulger, City police-sergeant, 89, and Michael Haydon, City-policeman, 21, stated that both prisoners were the constant associates of thieves, and that Lead's back-door was kept open all night for them; the witness Lead was committed for contempt of Court.)

1015.
CHARLES HOLMES
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Christian Riger, and stealing 12 pictures, I drinking-glass, and 1 chair, value 3s.; his goods.

CHRISTIAN RIGER . I live at 3, London-buildings, Whitecross-street, on the first-floor. The street floor is usually left open—the landlord does not live there—on 10th April I went out with my wife, about half-past seven o'clock—she fastened the door—we returned about twelve, and found the door broken open, and missed these pictures and other things—they are mine.
ESTHER RIOBR . I went out with my husband, and fastened the door with a key—I came hack, and missed these things.

CATHERINE PEARCE . I live in this house, on the ground-floor. On the night of 10th April, between eight and nine, I saw two boys come out of Mr. Riger's passage—one escaped—I laid hold of the prisoner, and said, "You have been robbing the place"—he said, "Oh, Mrs. Pearce, let me go, I will bring the things back"—I gave him to my husband.

JOHN PEDRO . I am an iron-dealer, of 5, London-buildings. I took the prisoner from Mr. Pearce—he asked to be let go, and he would show where the things were—I accompanied him to 4, Broad-yard, and he pro
duced these things.

GUILTY .* Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months, and
twice Whipped.

1016.
WILLIAM MARCH and
THOMAS SMART
, stealing 1 handker
chief, value Is.; the goods of
John Cotterill, from his person.

JOHN COTTERILL . On 16th March, about a quarter-past eleven o'clock, I stopped in Long-lane to look at a print-shop—a lady said something—I missed my handkerchief—it was safe not a minute before—some one pointed out the prisoners—an officer seized them, and took this handkerchief from March's pocket—(produced)—it is mine.

MICHAEL HAYDON (City-policeman, 2l). I saw the prisoners together for a quarter of an hour previous—I saw March put his hand into Mr. Cotterill's pocket, draw something out, and put it into his left trowsers pocket—I laid hold of his hand; he took it out, and I took this handkerchief from it—Smart stood so as to conceal him from the view of persons passing—they had made several attempts alternately before that.
JOHN SPITTLE (City-policeman, 9). I was with Haydon, and saw what he describes—both, prisoners were trying to pick pockets.
Smart's Defence. March came running up to me, and said he had found a handkerchief, and put it into his pocket

MARCH—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

SMART—
GUILTY .
Confined One Year.

1017.
RICHARD COLLINS
, breaking and entering the counting-house of
George Flynn, and stealing a model of a ship, value 15l.; his goods; having been before convicted: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Year.

div0.p: PRESENT—Sir CHAPMAN MARSHALL, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. GIBBS; Mr. Ald. SALOMONS; and EDWARD BULLOCK, Esq.

p.hi: Before Edward Bullock, Esq. and the Sixth Jury.

div1.p:
1018.
ANN COOPER and
HENRY PEACOCK
, unlawfully endea
vouring to conceal the birth of a child.
NOT GUILTY .

1019.
GEORGE THOMAS BUNKER
, stealing 1 sovereign; the moneys of
Henry William England.

HENRY WILLIAM ENGLAND . I am a surveyor and auctioneer. On 31st March I was at the Sutton Arms, Caledonian-road, Islington—I supped there with the landlord, and about half-a-dozen select friends—I was leaving to go to my own residence, about half-past eleven—as I fronted the bar, the pri
soner stood there with two other persons—I had seen him at my house the day before on business—he said, "What are you going to stand?"—I said, "Anything you like, but it is your turn"—he said, "I have no money"—I said, "Well, have what you like"—I ordered Mrs. Clayton to draw them what they liked—there were three glasses of brandy and water had, one of soda-water, and a cigar—it came to 2s.—I had one glass of brandy and water—I threw down a sovereign, and said to Mrs. Clayton, "Take for what we have had out of that"—she turned her head to a little parlour to get change, and the prisoner took up the sovereign and put it into his pocket—I said, "Don't be a fool; pull that sovereign out; let me pay for the reckoning"—he said, "I have not got it, I did not take it up, I have no money"—Mrs. Clayton came back, and the prisoner borrowed 2s. of one of his friends to pay the reckoning—he seemed in a jocular mood—I still insisted on having the sove
reign—we left the house, and came on towards my residence—I could not find a policeman—when we got to a coffee-shop, which was open, I said, "You shall go no further, I am determined to have the sovereign"—we went in there, and had some coffee—I sent a friend to fetch the policeman—the pri
soner still said he had not got the sovereign, he had not got any money at all—I saw the prisoner searched at the station—the sovereign was found in the pocket which I pointed out.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Where did you meet with the friend that you sent for the policeman? A. At the coffee-house door—he is my own family doctor—the prisoner said he lived in Chichester-place—he keeps a corn-dealer's shop, or something of that sort—he came to me the day before, and wanted a customer for the shop—I think my clerk wrote down the particulars—the supper that night began about half-past eight o'clock—I should say I might have had one glass more than enough—I had had about two glasses of brandy and water—I was sober, but not perfectly sober—I have been charged with felony—I was discharged in that case—I had paid for an article, and it appeared that the party who sold it me had not come by it properly—I tendered the receipt before the Magistrate, and he said that the prosecutor ought to be placed in my position—I charged a woman I had gone home with, with stealing a watch—it was afterwards brought to me by the policeman, and the woman was discharged—the Magistrate asked me whether I wished to press the charge, and said had I not better take the watch back—I did so—the Magistrate dismissed the case, but said he would leave it open for me to indict him—I preferred this bill, not behind the prisoner's back, he knew it perfectly well—I told him at the police that I would indict him—the Magistrate allowed the sovereign to be placed in the policeman's hands—he did not bind me over to prosecute.

CLAYTON. My husband keeps the Sutton Arms. England supped at our house on 31st March—when he was leaving, the prisoner asked him what he would stand—he said anything he liked to drink—they had brandy and water, and one of them had soda-water—Mr. England took a sovereign out of his pocket and told me to take the reckoning—he put it on the counter towards me—I went into the bar-parlour to get change—on my return I did

not find the sovereign—Mr. England said to the prisoner, "Why don't you put the sovereign down; you have got it in your left-hand pocket"—the prisoner said nothing, but borrowed 2s. of Mr. Nickling, and paid Mr. Clayton for the brandy and water—they seemed to be wrangling about the sovereign, and Mr. Clayton told them it was time to close the house—they then left.

JAMES ABRAHAMS (policeman, N 296). Mr. England gave the prisoner in my charge—the prisoner said he had no money: I am quite sure of that—when Smith asked for the pay for the tea, Mr. England said, "Who will pay for it?—the prisoner said, "I have got no money"—Mr. England paid for it—when I got within about 200 yards of the station the prisoner said, "I do not disown having a sovereign; I borrowed it"—when I got to the station I found a sovereign in his left-hand trowsers-pocket—Mr. England had said it was there.

Cross-examined. Q. Who fetched you? A. I cannot tell; some gentle
man, Mr. England was behind him—I was in Maiden-lane, about 200 yards from the coffee-shop—I do not think the prisoner or the prosecutor were sober—it was about twenty minutes before one o'clock—this case was heard before the Magistrate and dismissed—I heard the Magistrate say to Mr. England, "You can indict him at the Sessions if you like."
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did be direct you to keep the sovereign? A. Yes, till the case was settled.
NOT GUILTY .

1020.
CHARLES THOMAS AUSTIN
, stealing 413lbs. weight of lead, value 4l. 10s.: the goods of
Ebenezer Tonkin.

RICHARD COX . I am in the service of Mr. Glasbury, a butcher, of the Terrace, Kensington. On Friday night, 12th Jan., I saw the prisoner out
side the door, about ten o'clock, with five men—I had seen them about a quarter of an hour before—I saw the men potting some lead into a van before Mr. Tonkin's door—it came from under Mr. Tonkin's window—I saw the prisoner lifting up the tail of the lead into the van—another of the men said to the prisoner, "He has treated us very well, shall we have another pot?"—the prisoner said, "No, we won't have any more"—that man then walked off—the other four men then ran away, and the prisoner was left alone with the van—he got up into it and drove the horse off towards London—Fisk went in the same direction.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How near were you to them? A. Two or three yards—the Magistrate desired that the prisoner should be admitted to bail—I did not hear the men desire the prisoner to give them a lift up—the prisoner's name and address was on the van—Mr. Tonkin's house is the next house to the Adam and Eve—there is a court between—there is a large gas-light at the Adam and Eve—this lead was outside Mr. Tonkin's shop—if a man wanted to go from there to Knightsbridge on an improper errand there are plenty of bye-roads to go.

HENRY FISK (policeman, T 98). I received information from Cox, and overtook the van near Hyde-park-corner—the prisoner was driving—I desired him to stop—he drew up—I found in the van the piece of lead taken from Mr. Tonkin—there was another man in the van, who jumped out and ran away—I took the prisoner—the horse was warm, as if it had been run
ning—the prisoner said he had been hired by a man to go to Kensington to fetch some goods, but he did not go further than the Adam and Eve.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it a clipped horse? A. No—the lead was 3cwt. 2qrs. 21lbs.—it was a good horse—it was about two miles from the place it was taken from.

EBENEZER TONKIN . I am a plumber, of the Terrace, at Kensington. On the night of 12th Jan. I had some lead rolled up under my window—I saw it safe at eight o'clock—I afterwards met the cart and saw the lead—it was mine.

HENRY SAMUEL COOPER. I keep the Adam and Eve. I saw the prisoner about a quarter after nine on the night of the 12th Jan.—there was one other man with him, and several about—they drank together—he was at my house about three quarters of an hour.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the prisoner? A. No—I have ascer
tained that he was a soldier in the Guards, and that he lets out vans.

JOHN LOCK . I know the prisoner—he lets out vans. On the evening of the 12th of Jan. a man named Drake came to a house and inquired about him—the prisoner came, and Drake spoke to him about moving some goods.
NOT GUILTY .

1021.
EMILY PHILPOTTS
, stealing 1 pair of stockings, value 6d.; the goods of
John Willett.

JOHN HEATH . I am shopman to Mr. Willett, a linen-draper, of Barking. On the 20th March, in the afternoon, the prisoner came and bought several things, and paid me about 5s., for them—she returned, and desired to look at some black cotton stockings—I showed her some at 6d., and said we had some at 1/2 d.—she said she would take a pair at 6d.—I put them into her parcel with some more goods which she bought—after that, and as she was about leaving, I missed a pair of stockings—I told my master—he followed her out of the shop, sent for a constable, and found the stockings on her.

Prisoner. I paid for one pair—you took another pair and rolled them up in my parcel—I said I had one pair, and that was sufficient. Witness. You did not say so—I did not give you the second pair—you must have taken them while I went to inquire the price of a piece of print for you—I had counted the stockings by my master's order before putting them before you—you had been a customer before.

JOHN WILLETT . I saw the prisoner in the shop—I had reason to suspect her, and ordered Heath to count everything he put before her—he told me something—I stopped her going out of the shop, and accused her—she said she was sorry for what she had done, and would never do it again, if I would forgive her—I found the stockings in her apron, and the pair she had bought in the parcel.
Prisoner. I did not say so; I said if I had a pair not belonging to me, I did not know it. Witness. You did not.
JOSEPH MANSER (policeman, K 36.) I took the prisoner—she gave me this pair of stockings—as I took her to Ilford, she said she bought both pairs—there was another pair in her bundle.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

1022.
THOMAS WILLIAMSON
, stealing a pewter pot, value 1s. 2d.; the goods of
George Grant: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Seven Days.

1023.
JOHN BOWLING
, stealing 2lbs. weight of grease, value 1s.; the goods of the
Eastern Counties Railway Company; having been before con
victed: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Seven Yean.

1024.
WILLIAM WILSON
, stealing 1 sack, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Edwin Mollett and another.

RICHARD AMOS (policeman, E 390). On the night of 6th April, about half-past eleven, I was on duty on Chadwell-heath, and saw a wagon going towards London—after it had passed I saw the prisoner come from behind a shed, go to the back of the wagon, and take something off; I do not know what—he crossed the road towards a hedge, and was out of my sight about two minutes—he then crossed the road again and went towards his home—I knew him before, and knew where he lived—just before he got home he threw something over some timber, and went in doors immediately—I went to the place and found this sack (produced)—I then met Crawford, and we went to the prisoner's house and took him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Have you not had a quarrel with the prisoner? A. No—he was a little the worse for liquor—I never had a dispute with him, and said I would do for him some day—when I found the sack, the wagon was gone on towards London, and I went after the prisoner—he passed us just at his own door, and wished me good night—this was about eleven miles from London—the prosecutor's is about twenty miles from London.

JOHN DANCEY . I am Mr. Mollett's horse-keeper. On this night I was with the wagon, and had care of it—we were going towards London—there was a sack of potatoes on the tail—it was safe at a quarter-past eleven, when we were about 100 yards the other side of Chadwell-heath—when I got off the wagon at Ilford turnpike I missed it—this produced is it—it is Mr. Mollett's.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know it? A. By these particular places, and this hole is where I tied a string round to keep the potatoes in—I cannot say how many sacks of the same sort my master has got—I have been in his service fifteen or, sixteen months.

JAMES CRAWFORD (policeman, K 253). I met Amos about half-past eleven, and in consequence of what he said I went to Wilson's house and took him into custody—Amos produced this sack, the bottom of which was very dirty, as if it had been in some ditch—the front of the prisoner's smock was all over dirt the same as the sack.
CHARLES MOLLETT . I am in partnership with my brother, Edwin Mollett—this sack is our property.
NOT GUILTY .

1025.
JOSEPH HARRIS
, stealing 4 1l. 2 yards of doeskin, value 20s.; the goods of
Horatio Talbot.

JOSEPH BENTON (policeman, K 381). On the evening of 1st March, I saw the prisoner and another lad near Mr. Talbot's, the tailor's shop, at Strat
ford Church—I watched them about the shop for three quarters of an hour—the other lad went into the shop and took something out, crossed the road, and gave it to the prisoner, who was about three yards off when he went into the shop—I ran to them, and tried to take the prisoner—he dropped this cloth as I was grabbing him, and ran away—I kept close to him—a lad stopped him, and I took him.
GEOROB STRBETER . I am in Mr. Talbot's service—he has a shop in

Stratford—in consequence of what Benton said I missed a piece of doeskin; this produced is it—I know it by this shop-mark, which is my own doing—it is Mr. Talbot's property—I had seen it safe not half an hour before, on a piece of board standing up inside the shop-door.

CHARLES MILNER . I live in Dog-row, Mile End—I was coming from Woodford, and just by Stratford Church saw something on the path, picked it up, and it was this piece of cloth—it was three or four hundred yards from Mr. Talbot's shop—I saw a policeman and gave it him.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down the road, and a boy came across to me with a piece of cloth; he dropped it, and I did not have it at all.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months.

1026.
MARY GIBBONS
, stealing 1 bed, 1 nightgown, 1 scarf, and other articles, value 16s. 1d.; the goods of
William Vernon, her master.

WILLIAM VERNON . The prisoner was in my service nearly five months, and was going away on 9th April, in consequence of what my wife said to me—I told her to have the boxes searched—I saw this scarf taken from her box in her presence; it is my daughter's, who is ten years old; also a baby's night dress, which is my property—the other things were taken from her box before I got to the room; they are all my property—the prisoner did not say anything.

EMMA VERNON . I am the prosecutor's wife—the prisoner sent for me early in the morning to look at her boxes—when she was going away, and the boxes were corded up, I felt one box, and was certain it was heavier than it ought to be—it was opened in her and Rutherford's presence, and this feather bed and all this property (produced) found in it.
Prisoner. Q. Is the bed your property? A. Yes; it was what you used to sleep on—she said she was very sorry she had taken it, she had had a little drop to drink.

ANN RUTHERFORD . I am also in Mr. Vernon's service, and was present when the box was searched—I saw the bed found; it is Mr. Vernon's pro
perty; and the baby's bed-gown too—I know it by having a mark on it.
Prisoner's Defence. The bed is my own—master's bed is there still

GUILTY . Aged 36.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.—
Confined Eight Months.

1027.
HENRY SEXTON,
feloniously stabbing
John McCarthy, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JOHN MCCARTHY . I am a labourer of Stratford. On Sunday, 4th March, I met the prisoner, who I had worked with, and said, "Henry, you want shaving;" he said, "Yes, I do, Jack—I said, "Let me shave you," and shoved this broom across his face—he made a kick at me—I rubbed it across his face again; he. said "You b----b----, I will rip your b----guts open"—he put his basket down and pulled a knife out—I ran across the road, and did not know he was behind me till I felt him stab me—I said, "I am stabbed" he said, "Go along"—I put my hand behind me, and showed it him full of blood—I became senseless—Perry took me to a doctor.

JOHN PERRY . I am a boilermaker, and was with M'Carthy—I saw him brush the prisoner's face several times—the prisoner made a kick at him, and threw the basket from his shoulder; took a knife out, ran after him, and stabbed him, then picked up the basket and walked away—I heard him say, "You b----b----, I will rip your guts open if you do that again!"—I said,
"Harry, you have stabbed the man;" he said, "I know I have, and a b----good job too"—the broom did not strike him, it only brushed him.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I give you half my tobacco? A. Yes. SAMUEL WATFORD. I am an engineer—I saw M'Carthy brush the prisoner's face—the prisoner made a kick at him, and M'Carthy brushed him across the face again—the prisoner dropped his basket, took a knife out, opened it, put it by his side, and placed his right hand over the blade; M'Carthy brushed him across the face again and ran away; the prisoner ran after him and stabbed him—I said, "What a villain you must be to stab a man in the back like that;" he said, "He should have let me alone"—I asked a gentleman to hold him, and took the knife from his pocket—there was blood on the blade.

JOSEPH TUCKET (policeman). I found M'Carthy bleeding dreadfully from a wound in the side; I produce his trowsers, here is a cut in them corres
ponding with the wound—the prisoner said, "He should not have hit me with the broom."

WILLIAM HENRY HOLMAN . I am a surgeon at the London Hospital—the prosecutor was brought there on 4th March with a wound in the small of the back, an inch wide and an inch and a half deep; it had bled a great deal, it was not dangerous, but it would have been if it had been a little more on one side.

Prisoner. I have had my head cut open, and often do not know what I am doing; my head has been sown up; I have a scar two inches long. Witness. There are marks on his forehead and the top of his head—they are old wounds.

WILLIAM COX (Thamespoliceman). I have known the prisoner sixteen or eighteen years—he was always quiet and inoffensive—they play all manner of games with him, and push him down—his brother is an idiot.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 31.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

1028.
AMBROSE IVES
, feloniously assaulting
John Chandler, with intent to rob him. MR. PLUMPTREE
conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN CHANDLER . I am in the service of Mr. Dodenham, a coal and corn
dealer, of Lewisham. On 26th March, about eight at night, I was walking through Lewisham, carrying a truss of clover; I met the prisoner and a man I do not know; he pushed the clover off my back; I asked the reason, but had hardly got the words out, when the prisoner collared me and pushed me backwards into the ditch, and fell on me, with his hand on my throat—he put his left hand into my pocket while he held me down with his right—I had no money—I had him by the jacket; he asked me to leave go of him, which I did, and he ran and turned up Mr. Dadd's field.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you hit me with a fork, and say, "You b----r, what did you do that for?" A. No; you collared me—I knew you by sight—I am sure you are the man.

WILLIAM WILKINSON (policeman, R 235). On 26th March, between eight and nine o'clock, Chandler came to the station, and next morning I took the prisoner—I told him it was for assaulting a man and attempting to rob him—going

along he said, "I am the man, I knocked the truss off his shoulder, and we went into the ditch together, I punched his head twice; a little further on the man turned round on me with a fork, and I hit him, and got up and ran away."

Prisoner's Defence. I was the worse for drink, knocked against the hay, and it fell; he said, "You b----r, why did you do that;" I rushed into him, and shoved him into the ditch; he pulled me in with him; I caught hold of him with one hand and hit him with the other; I got up and ran away.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 19.—
Confined Six Month.

1029.
THOMAS CARTER
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 7s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Anthony Hand. MR. PLATT
conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS ANTHONY HAND . I am a bootmaker, of Woolwich—on 31st March, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was called, and saw the prisoner in the shop—he said he wanted a pair of Cossack boots—I fitted him with a pair—he said "I will have these; I have given the boy half-a-sovereign, the price is 9s."—he had not asked the price—the boy looked up astonished, and said, "You have not given me any money"—the price was 7s. 6d—he refused to take them off, and I sent for a constable—the boy was searched, and no money found on him, he bears a very good character—these boots are mine (produced).

CHARLES CARROLL . I am Mr. Hand's apprentice—on 31st March the prisoner came into the shop, and at that instant I called my master—the prisoner never said a word before he came—the first pair of boots fitted him—he said "I gave the boy half-a-sovereign"—I said, "You did not give me any money, sir"—the prisoner said, "The boy says the price of them is 9s."—I had not said so; the price was 7s. 6d.—he had given me no money.

JOHN FORSTER . I am a sergeant in the Royal Artillery—the prisoner belongs to that company—he was under stoppages, and has only received fourteenpence since June last—he was not likely to have half-a-sovereign.

THOMAS WHITEAR (policeman, R 258). I took the prisoner—he had a pair of new boots on, which he would not take off, but insisted on keep
ing them—I think he was sober—I searched Carroll, but found nothing on him.

Prisoner's Defence. The boy said he would get me a pair, and asked 9s. for them; I laid half-a-sovereign on the counter; when I said so, the boy denied it.
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Four Months.

1030.
GEORGE LARKIN
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Waite, and stealing 2 pairs of boots, 1 loaf, 8 ozs. of butter, and 1 cake, value 9s., his goods.

SARAH SARTAINE . I am servant to James Waite, of Acton-row, Wool
wich—on Sunday morning, 18th March, I came down about eight o'clock and found the kitchen and wash-house doors open—I was the first person down—persons could get from the yard into the wash-house, and from thence into the kitchen—I missed some butter and some boots from a cupboard which was not locked, and some lucifers from the mantel-piece—I had seen the things safe at ten o'clock the night before.
Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Are they not making a railway there? A. Yes, there are a great many navvies about.

ELIZABETH VEALE . I am Mr. Waite's mother-in-law—on 17th March I went to bed shortly after twelve o'clock—I was the last person up, and locked all the doors—the door between the kitchen and wash-house was
locked and bolted—I put a pair of boots on the safe in the cupboard—the butter was safe then—when I came down I missed a loaf and some cake, two pairs of boots and a towel.
Cross-examined. Q. Where was the towel? A. The cake was wrapped in it.

CAROLINE CAHILL . I am the wife of John Cahill, of 53, High-street, Woolwich, and keep a clothes-shop—on the Monday night, between nine and ten o'clock, the prisoner came to my shop with this pair of men's boots—he said they were his own—I gave him 2s. 3d. for them—I gave them to the con
stable—Chapman afterwards brought this other pair.

MART CHAPMAN . I am single—on 19th March, about eleven o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner at the Marquis of Granby—he asked me to go home with him, and gave me this pair of women's boots (produced) as he said he was short of money—I took them to Mr. Cahill's.
Cross-examined. Q. You are an unfortunate girl? A. Yes.

ELIZABETH VEALE
re-examined. These boots are my daughter's, and these others my son-in-law's.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1031.
JAMES JUPP
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 14s.; 2 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign; the property of
James Brooker: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

1032.
ANN CHICK
, stealing 1 shawl, 2 watches, 5 yards of satin, and other articles, value 20l.; the goods of
Alexander Davidson.

CAROLINE DAVIDSON . I am the wife of Alexander Davidson. In March, 1848, I lived at 3, Harding-street, Woolwich; it is now pulled down—the prisoner was a lodger of mine—on 18th, March she assisted me in cleaning the yard—I went into my room, and she said, "Oh! look at your chest of drawers and your boxes"—I said, "Oh! lam robbed!" and ran to the door to see if I could see any one—she said, "Sea if your watches are gone"—I looked and missed them, and a jacket, three pairs of trowsers, eleven waist
coats and shirts—I found a shirt in the passage, and two silver watches, one of which had hung over the mantel-piece, the other over the drawers, about three-quarters of an hour before—I also missed a satin dress, and a crape and cashmere shawl.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Was she married? A. Yes—she had lived at my house six months with her husband—she gave me warning that day—a policeman had been to inquire into the matter—they left before their week was up—her husband had gone out at half-past eight o'clock—he said he had nothing to do with taking the things—I saw them all safe after he left—I believe her husband left her in May, when he heard of the robbery—she has had a child since.

ELIZABETH CLARK . I am the wife of Charles Clark; the prisoner married my brother. I went to his house, 12, Kidd-street, Woolwich, in May, and found a duplicate of a shawl, among a variety of others which he gave me—he insisted on having the box opened, and she tore up a great many.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go with one of them to remove it? A. Yes; at the latter end of January this year—she had left my brother on the last day of May—a child was born on 3d June; it died at about nine weeks old, and he was summoned to pay the funeral expenses, and paid them—since she has been sent for trial, Mrs. Gale, her mistress, has sent for him—I do not know that he went to get her wages—he has not contributed to her defence to-day—the bonnet I have on does not belong to her—I bought it in Wool
wich—the
ribbon did belong to her—I have got two old bonnets of hers, which were left when she went away.
ALEXANDER DAVIDSON . This watch, trowsers, and handkerchief are mine and were taken from my dwelling-house.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A boiler-maker. I was present when a bundle, containing a satin gown-piece, a watch, waistcoat, and other articles, was found in the cesspool, when the house was pulled down.

JOSHUA THORPE . I am a pawnbroker. I produce these things pawned on 20th March, 1848, by a female, in the name of "Mary Taylor"—this shawl was pledged in June, and renewed last January, in the name of "Ann Chick;" here is the duplicate—the prisoner has frequently pledged in the name of "M'Donald."

Cross-examined. Q. How lately? A. Not for nine or ten months—I do not think I have seen her since May 31st—some of the tickets have been re
newed since, by Clark, and other persons.

CHARLES MAY (policeman, R 296.)
