The prisoner was in my employment about two years—I discharged him on 10th March—he was employed to go about and take orders, and receive money for me—he took some goods to Mrs. Dennison's on 17th Feb. to the amount of 5s., and on 21st to the amount of 10s., and some on 9th March—I have a customer named Blaber—there was a dispute about 2s. 9 1/2 d. alleged to be received from her—he has never paid me these sums—when he returned on 21st I asked him if Mrs. Dennison had paid—he said, "No"—I said that made two bills—on 9th March, when be brought 10s., I told him there was 5s. before, which was not paid—he went a second time, and I told him to mention the 5s.—he returned, and said there was some one in the shop, which was the reason he did not.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. If he received money when was it his duty to give it to you? A. The moment he returned—he has not had money by him, nor have we accounted together after the lapse of a day or two, we perhaps have after an hour or two—I spoke to him about the 2s. 9 1/2 d.—he brought me a bill afterwards, and I told him there was a bill before—I know he lost a sovereign of mine, and was afraid to tell me, and this was done for the purpose of making it up—he said when he was discharged he thought I should apply to his father, and he would pay the money—he has always made that statement—he has never stated when he lost it—the first deficiency was in Feb., the last in the beginning of March—he had 7s. a week,

and sometimes had his breakfast—he was what I called an errand-boy—he has collected a quantity of money for me in small amounts—the whole amount of cases against him amount to 1l. 0s. 9 1/2 d.—I have no means of knowing he lost a sovereign, he has had as much—he continued to account to me while these matters were going on.
JAKE DENNISON . In Feb. I paid the prisoner 5s. for some butter—he gave me this receipt—it has no date.
LYDIA BLABER . I paid the prisoner 2s. 9 1/2 d. for his master—this is his receipt.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder,

1054.
JOHN BLAXALL,
stealing 90 canvas bags, value 19s.; the goods of
George Swaine and an other, in a barge on the Thames; and
ABRAHAM FINCH
, feloniously receiving the same.
MR. CLERK conducted the Prosecution,

RICHARD BANNER . On 7th March, I had a barge lying at Dock-head—I saw Blaxall on board, putting guano bags over the side of the barge—he put one lot over before I went to him, and one lot after—I said, "You young rascal, what are you doing here? You will get transported"—he jumped out of the barge—there were two or three other boys—I missed the bags.

RICHARD ARNOTT . I am manager of the establishment of George Swaine and George Penton Bovile, at the London Docks. On 7th March they had some guano bags on a barge—I saw them safe at twelve o'clock in the day, partly covered with a tarpaulin—I missed them on Wednesday—there are thirty-eight gone, and a quantity of old ones—I found the thirty-eight new ones at Finch's, the marine store dealer's—they had never been used—there was a hundred-weight of old ones besides—this is one of them (produced)—the only mark is our twine—they are worth about 6d. each; 19s. altogether.
Cross-examined by MR. PATNE. Q. How can you swear to them? A. By this tar twine—there is no mark on them—these bags are confined to holding guano, which is only imported by two houses in London.

JAMBS RITCHIE, JUN . I and my father manufactured these bags expressly for Swaine and Bovill—their private mark is in the cloth—it came from Scotland—we have sold thousands of them—they are made in a particular way for guano.
WILLIAM RITCHIE . I am manufacturer of these bags. I have not sold any of them with a mark on them to any one but Swaine and Bovill.

Cross-examined. Q. Does not this "W" come from Scotland? A. Yes; we have sold others of this quality; but not of this size—I know it from the mark, and the way in which it is made—the "W" is not on any of the others; this is only a chance one—a piece cuts into 170 bags—those are worth from 5d., to 5d. per bag, wholesale.

WILLIAM MEGGS (policeman). On 7th March I was passing Finch's shop, Fashion-street, Dock-head, about two hundred yards from Swaine and Bovill's wharf, and saw Blaxall talking to Mrs. Finch—I went on and saw a policeman, and then went back to Finch's shop, and saw his wife—he was in the back-yard—these guano bags hung on a line, and others lay about the yard—some were screwed up, as if to screw the water out—a hundred-weight of them have been used—I took Finch—he said he bought them as old rags, at a half-penny perlb.—I took Blaxall in Bermondsey.
Cross-examined. Q. How long has Finch been there? A. I believe he went there about Christmas—some of the bags were wet—he gave me this book (produced)—here is an entry in it, "Bagging, 3s. 9d., 10d."

JOHN FLETCHER (policeman.) I went into Finch's yard, and saw some bags lying down and some on a line, and said to my mate, "Here they are"—Finch came, saw the bags, and said, "Are they stolen?"—I said, "Yes;" and asked how much he had given for them—he said a halfpenny, perlb., and that he bought them of two boys, in three lots, at 8d., 10 1/2 d. and 3s. 9d.
Cross-examined. Q. There Was no attempt to conceal them? A. Nc; from what the wife said, I went into the yard.
Blaxall's Defence. I asked the boys where they got the bags; they said they found them in the river.
(Finch received a good character.)

FINCH.—
NOT GUILTY .

BLAXALL.—
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months.

1055.
WILLIAM CRAWLEY and
GEORGE PEACOCK
, feloniously forging a warrant for the delivery of 5,000lbs. weight of flour, and 20 sacks, with intent to defraud the
South-Eastern Railway Company.—2d COUNT, for uttering the same.

CRAWLEY—
NOT GUILTY .

MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution. JOHN FOTHEROILL. I am manager of the Goods Department of the South-Eastern Railway Company at the Bricklayer's Arms' station. In December last there was a quantity of flour placed there from Mr. Feltham, of Crawley Mills, consigned to Mr. Empson; according to the custom, that flour would be delivered to the written orders of Mr. Empson—some of it bad been delivered—we were regularly delivering the flour to the orders of Mr. Empson—Mr. Wells, our delivering clerk, is the person to whom such orders are directed.

EDWARD CLAWSON . I am foreman in the employ of the South-Eastern Railway Company. This order (looking at it) was brought by Crawley—he was there when I went there, at seven o'clock in the morning, or it might be three minutes after; it was scarcely light—he had a man and a cart with him—in consequence of receiving this order, twenty-five sacks of flour were delivered to him—there were fifteen sacks of household flour, and ten sacks of No. 2—they were delivered by the order of Mr. Empson—here is the delivery-book—Crawley has signed it, in the name of John Roberts—on 20th Dec. Crawley brought this other order for twenty sacks—I delivered the quantity mentioned to him—he had again to sign the delivery-book for them—they were taken away the same as before—it was about the same time in the morning—they were there when I came—seven o'clock is the time to deliver.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. There were two occasions? A. Yes, the 14th and 20th Dec.; but the orders are dated the 12th and the 18th Dec.—I did not know Crawley before—he did not give any account of himself, he only said he wanted the quantity of flour—he just gave me the orders, and I gave them to Blake—the flour was delivered according to the I order—we had only one sort of flour of this description, and these marks—if Crawley had been in the habit of coming with vans to the station be could see where these sacks were; they were all visible—I did not notice whether there was any name on the van, it was dark—Crawley was not alone on the first occasion; one of Boddy's carmen was with him—I know Mr. Empson's signature—I should say this signature to the order is not his—I might have given these sacks on a signature purporting to be his, which was not his, in the height of business—there might have been four or five more vans waiting—I cannot say whether there were any more—I did not look particularly at it—I saw "T. Empson" on it.
MR. BODKIN. Q. If Crawley came, and saw the flour, could he know that Mr. Empson's signature would obtain it? A. No, I should think not.

THOMAS JOSEPH EMPSON . I am agent to Mr. Feltham; he consigns flour to me to supply his customers—these orders are not my handwriting, they are forgeries, they were not written by my authority—I had not sold any flour to a person of the name of Wilson about that time.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the way in which this flour is sold in the market, by samples or by description? A. That all depends on the person who buys it—most persons know the character of flour, and buy it without a sample, and an order is given by me to deliver it—if a person were to get this order, it would not act in the same way as a bill of parcels; it is a delivery-order—I am known as a dealer—it would be known in the trade to what description of flour my order pointed—if my order were brought to a person who knew what the flour trade was, he would know what he was buying, on my order—the flour which is consigned to me is of a particular sort—I have a certain connection that I go amongst, and sell it to—this order is like a dock-warrant—I should buy flour on a note of this kind, if I knew the man whose flour it was, but I should like to know the quality of the flour—I issue perhaps four or five of these orders in the course of a week—I had one cus
tomer named Wilson—I did not sell to Wilson about that time; he never bought this quantity.
COURT. Q. Supposing I came to you, would you, on my statement, and this order being delivered to you, buy these goods? A. Yes, I should.

MR. BODKIN. Q. You go to your particular customers and show them samples? A. I do not; they know the quality—if I went to a stranger I should very likely have to show a sample, unless they made inquiry about the quality of it; I then give the delivery-order—I have never known that when I have given a customer a delivery-order, that that customer has gone into the market and sold it.

JURY. Q. Could any person go and sell these tickets, or sell upon these tickets; suppose he were to go to a Mr. Thompson, and say, "I have got these sacks, they are not delivered," could that person buy them? A. I never knew such a thing—it might be done, the one having faith in the other—I write the orders on the railway.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Supposing a person to be in possession of orders of this kind, but it. being inconvenient for him to take the flour, and supposing he were acquainted with another person, would it be possible for him to sell that order? A. He must give another order for it, or he must back that order, or else that person must say he was Mr. Wilson, or whoever the order was made to.

MR. BALL AN TINE . Q. Are these the ordinary form of your orders? A. Yes, something similar to them—we employ a regular wharfinger in the Borough; I send the orders to him—I give an order, on which the railway act—if you bought a quantity of flour I should give you an order to fetch it—I should not say that any person who produces a genuine order would have the flour delivered to him—if I get a customer and give him an order, and he gives it to a porter or carman, he must sign the order—this order is not signed—I have heard that the flour has been delivered on this unbacked order—I do not understand this—if it is signed over from one to another, and a person chooses to do it, I have nothing to do with that—I do not understand buying the orders, I never bought them—in a general way we deliver the flour we sell by our own carts, I give a delivery order of this kind to our own carman, but supposing a man has his own carman, I give him the order, and he
sends for it himself—I have been in trade fourteen or fifteen years—I have never met with an instance in which an order has been transferred from one to another; but it is possible.

WILLIAM CRAWLEY (the prisoner). I am a carman and coal-merchant—Peacock employed me on 14th Dec. to fetch some flour from the railway station—he first spoke to me about fetching it as I was washing my van before my own door one morning between twelve and one o'clock—he said, "Holloa, Crawley, how are you?"—I said I was rather slack of work—he said, "I can give you an order to cart some coals"—I said, "I expect a country job; I cannot do that"—he said, "Well, I expect I shall buy some flour worth the money;" and he asked me how much I would cart it for—I told him 6d. a sack—he said it was to be carted from the Bricklayers' Arms station to his house—I said I would not do it under 6d. a sack; he said he could get it done for 4d.—I said I did not care about it—a few days after, I was coming out of my door to go after some coals in my cart, and he said, "Good morn
ing;" I said, "Good morning"—he said, "I have got an order for twenty-five sacks of flour, it belongs to a man of the name of Roberts"—he gave me this order (looking at it) for twenty-five sacks—he told me to go and get them; and he said, "Sign Roberts, or what you like"—he told me I was to get it early in the morning, but it was all coming to his place—to the best of my belief it was about three or four o'clock in the afternoon when he brought this order—I said I could not get it away myself with my horse and van—he said, "Can you hire?" I said, "Yes, I can; I often hire from Mr. Boddy, close by me"—we went to the public-house, and had a drop of gin—I think he stood one drop, and I stood another—I went down to Boddy's in the even
ing; I saw his foreman, and made an arrangement with him for the following morning-next morning I went to the railway station, about half-past six o'clock; I took my own van and horse, and Boddy's man went with me with his cart and horse-when I got to the station I gave in this order to a person there; he said, "You must wait, you cannot have the flour till the delivery-foreman comes"—I went to a coffee-shop, and while I was there, a tall man came in, and in consequence of what he said I went to the station and obtained the twenty-five sacks of flour, leaving the order there—the man who came into the coffee-shop helped to load the flour—I afterwards described that man to Peacock, and he said he thought, by the description I gave of the man, that he was the man of whom he bought some of the flour, of the name of Bailey (that was when we were in prison)—having obtained the flour, I drew it from the station, and took it to Peacock's shop in St. George's-road, near the Elephant and Castle, it was there unloaded, and placed in his shop—I noticed the mark of "J. M." was on the sacks—Peacock then went with roe, and we had some half-and-half to drink—I was not paid in money, I had a sack of oats for my horse and some chaff to the value of 12s. 6d., which the job came to—he asked me if I had signed the name of Roberts in the book—I said, "Yes;" he said, "That is all right, old fellow"—I had signed the name of "Roberts"—a few days afterwards, on 20th Dec, I went again to the station—it was on Monday morning, about half-past six o'clock, when I started from Boddy's—I took an order there for twenty sacks—this is the order, I received it from my wife on the Sunday night when I came home, and she told me something, in consequence of which I got ready, and went on the Monday morning—I got Boddy's man and one of his horses—the order I got was signed "Roberts"—I got the twenty sacks, and took them to Peacock's house—I was paid for that in corn and chaff—he asked me if I had signed the name of "Roberts"—I said, "Yes;" he said, "That is all right, old fellow" Peacock said he bought the orders of two men, Bailey and Wilson; and had

Mr. Fothergill asked him of whom he had bought it, he should have told him of two men, Bailey and Wilson; but Mr. Fothergill asked him whether he had bought any flour of Wilson and Empson—he told me that in prison—I remember Mr. Fothergill coming to ask me a question about this—I had been drinking, and I said, "What?"—I afterwards went before the Magistrate, and was admitted to bail.

Cross-examined. Q. You were quite an innocent man in this matter? A. Yes; I was not at all aware that the orders were forged, or that I was doing anything wrong—I refused to tell the superintendent, because I had been drinking, but as soon as he sent for a policeman, the policeman could see that I did not see the nature of the charge—I was obstinate, because. I had been drinking; if I had been sober I should have given every information—Peacock did not tell me not to tell anything about it, or to disguise anything—when I was locked up, he came to my wife, and said I was an innocent man, and what was done was done by his desire; she was broken hearted about it—Peacock told me at the time why he wished the name of Roberts to be used—he said he had bought it of a man named Roberts; and said, Sign Roberts, or what you like, it is all coming to my place"—I had never fetched anything from the station before—I have taken goods there, but I never fetched anything away with orders—Peacock keeps a corn dealer's shop—I believe he took it two or three years ago from a man named Perry—I was taken up, and Peacock came before the Magistrate—to the best of my belief I was only examined once before the Magistrate—Peacock did not appear on that occasion—he went to my wife, and said I was discharged from custody—I saw some books produced at the office, they were in a handkerchief—I believe Peacock brought them himself—I do not think they were looked at—I did not direct my attorney to summon Peacock to appear—he did summon him, and he appeared.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Are you sure he said he bought this flour of a man of the name of Roberts? A. Yes; that was on the first occasion.

JOHN WATSON . I am one of Mr. Boddy's men—I remember going with Crawley to fetch some flour—that was the first time he went—I loaded twelve sacks, and there were thirteen loaded in the other van—they were taken to Peacock's shop—he was in the way and took them in.
JOHN ADAMS . I am a carman to Mr. Boddy. I went the second time with Crawley for the flour—we got twenty sacks—they were drawn to Peacock's house, and taken in there by him.

JOHN FOTHERGILL
re-examined. Shortly after the delivery of this flour, it was discovered that the orders were forged, and in consequence of what I learned I went to Peacock's shop—I saw him and asked if he had purchased flour from a gentleman named Wilson or Empson—he said he really could not tell, as he was in the habit of purchasing almost daily from any one—I asked him to turn to his books or papers, and see if he had purchased flour from Wilson or Empson—I told him that a robbery had been committed at the Bricklayers' Arms station, that one load was taken on the 14th December, and one on the 20th, and I should feel obliged if he would give me the information that I wanted—I then asked him if he had purchased twenty-five sacks on the 14th of December, or if it had been delivered at his place on the 14th—he said he believed not—I particularly mentioned the names of Wilson and Empson, and his answer was, "believe not"—I asked him to turn to his papers and see, as his memory would not assist him—in looking over his receipt file, he found a receipt for twenty sacks, signed "Wilson"—that was on the 20th—the date of the receipt, I believe, was the 21st—he showed me that, and said he understood these twenty sacks came from the railway, but he was not

really positive—he said it was purchased of Mr. Wilson, and the signature of Wilson was on the receipt—I asked him if he knew Mr. Wilson—he said he had never seen the man that he purchased it of in his life before, nor had he seen him since, that he had called a few days before, with the samples and left them, and he called again and he gave him an order, and be sent it in on the 20th and called the same day for the money—I asked him if he knew who was the carman that brought the flour—he said he did not know who was the carman—after this explanation of the twenty sacks, I asked him to go back to the 14th and see if he had not received twenty-five sacks of flour—I do not recollect that I mentioned any names then—he went through his files and beyond the 14th, and said he could not find any receipts, and therefore he had not had the flour—I saw a cash-book there, and I asked him if he could find anything in his cash-book that would tally with the amount—he said, "Nothing of the kind"—I asked him if it was usual to buy sacks of flour without knowing the name of the person he bought them of—he said it was quite usual with him—I asked him about buying the twenty-five sacks generally—I do not know that I mentioned any name—I asked him whether he had any of the flour in his possession—he said he had not, he had sold it—he said he could not recollect who he had sold it to—I asked him whether the sacks had been returned—he said he believed not—he said he seldom gave himself any trouble about the sacks, it was seldom they were returned—I showed him these two orders—he looked at them, and I said particularly to him, "Do you know Empson P—he said, "No, I bought the flour of Wilson"—I asked him particularly if he had seen any orders—he said,"No," I had the orders with me, the questions and dates were given from the orders.

Cross-examined. Q. What was the day on which you put the prisoner through this course of cross-examination? A. I do not recollect the day—I found it out on 1st February—I was not sent to Peacock's, it became me as manager to make these inquiries—I saw Peacock in his own shop—there was corn and flour there; not a great deal, there might have been forty or fifty sacks—I will not swear there were not a hundred—Mr. Church, the solicitor, was present—he took notes—I have never seen his notes—he was not seated at a table—he stood against the counter, and took it down there—I do not know that Peacock saw him writing—he could have seen him if he thought proper—I have no doubt that he saw him—I did not wait to give Church time to take down all the answers—I had not arranged the plan of operations with Church before I went there—we had no idea of Peacock being in the situation he was—Mr. Church's notes have not been read to me—I will not pledge myself that I have left out nothing that occurred—I have left out nothing—part of the answer Peacock gave me was "I cannot tell without looking at my books"—I asked him to look over his papers—he produced two books—there were other books produced at the police-court, he had some books in a handkerchief—I did not leave him a summons to attend the police-court—I did not desire him to attend—I will swear that no notice was given him in my presence—I believe a notice was sent him by the Magistrate, and he attended, and brought his books—I do not recollect that he invited the Magistrate's attention to them, I believe he did not—I think I should have recollected it if it had been so—I should suppose he brought them for the purpose of giving information—I saw in the handkerchief what had the appearance of books—the Magistrate and I had been talking the matter over, and when Peacock came with his books, he was slipped into the dock—I did not know that that was to be done—I did not apply for a summons for him—I do not know that one was applied for—I know he was there—I saw the other man Crawley—when I asked him, he said he did not know anything about

them—I told him I was in possession of information—he then said he should answer no question, I could just go and do. what I liked—I cannot say that he was drunk; he was not sober—I saw a woman at the door—I did not see any family—I did not go to Peacock's premises after he was locked up—I had been there several times for the purpose of seeing him, and he was away—his wife did not show me over the stable.
MR. BODKIN. Q. When you and Mr. Church went in the first instance did you at all suspect him of this? A. No; I merely went to make inquiries to trace the flour.

MR. BALLAUTINE.
Q. Are these the books that were produced (producing some)? A. To the best of my belief they are not—I would not swear it, but to the best of my belief they were thinner books than these.
EDWARDS. I am a corn-dealer, and live in the New Cut,

Lambeth. On 22d Dec. I purchased five sacks of flour of Peacock—this is the invoice of three of them; Mr. Peacock wrote it—the flour was delivered on that day—it was in five sacks with "J. Feltham" on them—I have had dealings with Peacock for twenty years—it was very well known who the flour was sold to.

Cross-examined. Q. When did he sell these to you? On 22d Dec.; he made application to me on that day—I went and looked at the flour—he said he had purchased it of some man—I think it was Bailey or Wilson—I have always found Peacock to be an honest well-conducted man—I never heard anything against him—I know his hand-writing—these orders are decidedly not his handwriting—I have seen orders like these—if I were furnished with an order of this kind I should send to the railway and get the articles—I have bought orders on the railway, but they have been printed from the Corn-Exchange—there would be nothing at all unusual in buying orders of this kind—I do not know Mr. Empson's signature—I never purchased any of him—I know that he had flour at the station.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you ever have in your possession an order drawn by another person for the delivery of flour? A. I do not recollect that I ever had—I do not discover any letters in these orders like the prisoner's writing.
CHARLES FRANCIS . I am a corn-dealer—I have known Peacock six or seven years—I have had dealings with him—I have frequently seen him write—I believe these orders to be his writing.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you see him write? A. Four or five months since—I saw him write an order in my own shop—I have seen him write several times—this is his ordinary handwriting, there is no disguise at all about it—the letters are just as he usually writes, with the exception that these may be written a little better than he ordinarily writes—he generally writes in a hurry—the prosecutors found me at my own house—they brought these things to me to look at—I went with Mr. Fothergill to Mr. Edwards, and showed Mr. Edwards these documents—I know plenty of persons who are well-acquainted with Peacock's hand-writing—there might have been fifty called here that I know—I went to one of them, Mr. Wilkins, to ask if he could prove Peacock's handwriting—he would not come up to the mark—I did not try anybody else after that—I know Mr. Shingles, of Lime-street—he is no friend of mine—I know Mrs. Shingles—I went to their shop, Mr. Fothergill was with me—I did not tell Mrs. Shingles that if her husband knew Peacock's handwriting that Mr. Fothergill would give him a leg up, or could give him a leg up, or any words of that kind—I said that Mr. Fothergill wanted some information respecting Peacock's handwriting; that was all I said—to the best of my belief I did not go any where else with

Mr. Fothergill to find out somebody beside myself who knew Peacock's writing—I am not often engaged in this sort of chase—I was waited on by Mr. Fothergni—h was no business of mine beyond being asked—I supply the Railway Company with corn.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you first go to Mr. Wilkins? A. No; I first went to Mr. Edwards—I there saw an invoice—my knowledge of Peacock's writing is not founded on the comparison of these two documents—as far as my belief will carry me, it was Peacock's writing without comparison—I went with Mr. Church to Mr. Wilkins, who is a corn-dealer in the market—a question was put to him as to whether he was competent to speak to Peacock's writing—the answer was, he was not—I did not show these to Wilkins, or Shingles.

CRAWLEY. I am the wife of William Crawley. I remember his going out early one Monday morning to fetch the second parcel of flour—I was at home on the Sunday night before, and my husband was out—while he was out, Mr. Peacock came; I believe about ten o'clock—I had gone to bed and got up, and went down in my night clothes, and spoke to him—he left an order with me, for my husband, for twenty sacks of flour—he said my husband was to sign the name" J. Roberts as before—he said he was to go early in the morning—I told my husband, and he went in the morning.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you seen your husband's statement? A. No, I have not read it; I heard my husband reading it to his brother-in-law.
(Peacock received a good character.)

PEACOCK—
GUILTY of Uttering. —Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Eighteen Months.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoner.)

1056.
JAMES JONES and
JOHN KEEFE
, stealing 1 pair of trowsers, and 1 coat, value 10s.; the goods of
James Rayford; and 1 coat, and 1 pair of trowsers, value 10s.; the goods of
Edward Rayford; Keefe having been before convicted.

JAMES RAYFORD . I am mate of the schooner Richard Hill lying in the river. On 17th March, between two and three o'clock in the morning, I got out of bed and went on deck—I tried to push the state-room door open, I found a man stood in the doorway; he went on deck and went over the stern—I sung out "Police!" the police-boat went after them—I saw them heaving some things overboard—I sent a boat and picked up this coat and trowsers, across a chain in the water—they belong to Edward Rayford, the captain—they were hanging in the cabin—these others are mine.

JAMES GIBBON (Thames police-officer 61). I heard a cry of: "Police!"—I took the prisoners in a skiff they bad nothing in the boat—I saw the prisoners in the midships of the vessel, and saw them shove off from it—there was no other boat there.
Jones. We were going across the water in a boat, and when we got half way the police came and charged us; we had nothing.
JOSEPH SMITH (Thames-police-constable 17). I produce a certificate of Keefe's conviction—(read—Convicted April, confined six months.—he is the person.
JONES—GUILTY. Aged 19.-Confined Six Months.

KEEFE*—
GUILTY Aged 22.—
Confined One Year.

1057.
WILLIAM BARNETT
, stealing 200 bricks, value 4s.; the property of
John Richard Nicholl Clerk.
EBENEZER SEAGER . I am in the service of John Richard Nicholl Clerk, the prisoner was a bricklayer in his employ—the top course of a wan was

pulled down, and instead of replacing the bricks be took them away—I found him with the truck loaded with them—I stopped him and told him to take them back—he had three men with him, whom he had employed to do a job with these bricks—he said, "There were enough of them to throw me into the ditch"—I followed the bricks and got an officer and took them; this is one of them, they are all marked "W. G."
SAMUEL MANSFIELD . I saw the prisoner take the bricks off the house, bring them down the ladder, and take them away.

Prisoner. He plays at pitch and toss all day on Sunday; he has been a fatherless child; I have brought him up; he has done but six months' work these eighteen years. Witness. When I was ill he turned me out because I could not work; my mother brought me up, not him—my mother lives with him—I cannot read.
CHARLES BULLPIT . I am employed by Mr. Seager to repair these houses—I was on one time and the prisoner another—I found the party wall stripped—these bricks belonged to that wall.
THOMAS CHILD . I lived with the prisoner; I know he had no bricks belonging to him; he had none on his own premises.
THOMAS RICHARDS (policeman M 44). These are the bricks, they are all marked "W. G."—the prisoner said they were his own—he had taken them best part of a mile and was working them into a chimney.
Prisoner's Defence. I have been a master bricklayer nine years—I have had from ten to twelve thousand bricks—it is all from prejudice.

GUILTY .—
Confined Fourteen Days.

1058.
SAMUEL IVES was indicted
for embezzlement.

MICHAEL NICHOLSON . I live in Castle-street, Southwark, and am a hat-block turner—the prisoner was in my service, and it was his duty to receive money for me—if he received one shilling and one shilling and sixpence, he has not paid them to me—he ought to have paid them on the 17th and 18th Feb., directly be returned, but I never saw him afterwards.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Did you not see him on the 17th? A. Yes; he went on my errands mostly—he was the only boy I had—I paid him 3s. 6d. a week, and then advanced him to 5s.—he collected money on Sundays, but it was his own wish—he had not complained to me of not being paid regularly—I have lent him money and never stopped it—I never saw him hungry—I have sent him out dinner.
SARAH BAYLEY . I paid the prisoner 1s. for his master on 17th Feb. about half-past seven o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure it was not on 10th Feb.? A. Yes; it was for half-a-dozen fancy blocks—I cannot tell when they had come; they had been in the house some weeks.
PETRONELLE HAUSSLIN I paid the prisoner 1s. 6d. on 18th Feb.
Cross-examined. Q. What day of the week was it? A. On Sunday.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Six Days.

1059.
MARY DONOVAN
, stealing 1 blanket, 1 shift, and other articles, value 8s. 3d.) the goods of
Morris James Harriss: to which she pleaded
GUILTV. Aged 35.—Confined Six Months.
1060. JOHN MANSFIELD, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 15s.; the goods of Frederick Garratt; having been before convicted to which he pleaded

GUILTY .** Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years *
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, 7TH MAY, 1849.

div0.p:
The following Prisoners, in whose cases judgment was at the time of convic
tion respited, have been sentenced as under:
Wynn, Robert... 476 Transported for seven years.
Jennings, John... 20 Transported for fourteen years.
Shaw, Mary Ann... 282 Confined ten days.
Albert, Henry... 328 Transported for seven years, and sever years more.
Howard, Henry... 328 Transported for seven years.
Killerby, Henry Joseph... 416 Transported for fifteen years.
